questions.question: Mechanoreceptors in the mammalian inner ear transduce sound waves into electrical signals. Which statement best describes the molecular mechanism of hair cell transduction?
options: Sound waves cause hair cells to release acetylcholine, which activates auditory nerve fibers through nicotinic receptors
Sound waves directly activate voltage-gated sodium channels in hair cells
Hair cells transduce sound through G-protein coupled metabotropic receptors that generate IP3 second messengers

Sound waves cause vibration of the basilar membrane, which deflects stereocilia on hair cells; tip links connecting adjacent stereocilia pull open mechanically gated ion channels (primarily permeable to K+ and Ca2+), depolarizing the hair cell and triggering neurotransmitter release at its basal synapse
questions.explanation: Hair cell mechanotransduction is one of the fastest sensory processes in biology. Stereocilia on each hair cell are arranged in rows of increasing height and connected by tip links composed of cadherin-23 and protocadherin-15. When sound-induced vibration of the basilar membrane deflects stereocilia toward the tallest row, tip links stretch and pull open mechanically gated transduction channels (TMC1/TMC2 are leading candidates). These channels are nonselective cation channels permeable to K+ and Ca2+. Uniquely, the endolymph bathing the stereocilia tips has high K+ concentration (~150 mM) maintained by the stria vascularis, creating an electrochemical driving force that pushes K+ into the hair cell. The resulting depolarization opens voltage-gated Ca2+ channels at the basal end, triggering glutamate release onto afferent auditory nerve fibers. Option B is wrong because the initial transduction uses mechanically gated, not voltage-gated channels. Option C describes a metabotropic mechanism not used here. Option A incorrectly identifies the neurotransmitter — hair cells use glutamate, not acetylcholine.

questions.question: In vertebrate photoreception, the phototransduction cascade in rod cells involves a decrease in cGMP upon light absorption. What is the immediate consequence of this decrease?
options: cGMP-dependent protein kinase phosphorylates rhodopsin, inactivating it

Cyclic nucleotide-gated (CNG) channels in the outer segment close, reducing the inward Na+ and Ca2+ current (the dark current), causing the rod cell to hyperpolarize from about -40 mV to approximately -70 mV
The rod cell depolarizes, increasing glutamate release at the synaptic terminal
Decreased cGMP activates phospholipase C, generating IP3 and releasing Ca2+ from intracellular stores
questions.explanation: In darkness, rod photoreceptors maintain high cGMP levels (~3 µM) that keep CNG channels open in the outer segment plasma membrane. These channels conduct an inward current of Na+ and Ca2+ (the 'dark current'), maintaining the cell at a relatively depolarized resting potential of about -40 mV. When light activates rhodopsin, the G-protein transducin activates phosphodiesterase 6 (PDE6), which rapidly hydrolyzes cGMP to 5'-GMP. A single photon can trigger hydrolysis of ~1000 cGMP molecules through this amplification cascade. The resulting drop in cGMP causes CNG channels to close, stopping the inward dark current. The Na+/K+-ATPase and K+ leak channels in the inner segment continue to pump out Na+ and allow K+ efflux, causing net hyperpolarization to approximately -70 mV. This hyperpolarization reduces voltage-gated Ca2+ channel activity at the synaptic terminal, decreasing glutamate release. Option A confuses kinase action — rhodopsin kinase (GRK1) does phosphorylate rhodopsin but as a shutdown mechanism, not a cGMP effect. Option C is the opposite of what occurs. Option D describes an unrelated signaling pathway.

questions.question: The sliding filament model of muscle contraction describes how sarcomeres shorten. During a power stroke, which structural change occurs?
options: Thick filaments contract by folding their myosin tails inward
Actin filaments shorten by depolymerizing at their minus ends

Myosin heads undergo a conformational change from a 90° to a 45° angle relative to the thick filament, pulling actin filaments toward the M-line and shortening the sarcomere without changing the length of either thick or thin filaments
Titin molecules actively pull Z-discs closer together using ATP hydrolysis
questions.explanation: The sliding filament model, proposed by Huxley and Hanson (1954), explains that sarcomere shortening occurs by thin (actin) filaments sliding past thick (myosin) filaments without either filament changing length. During a cross-bridge cycle, myosin heads bind ATP, hydrolyze it to ADP + Pi (cocking the head to ~90°), then bind actin. Release of Pi triggers the power stroke — a conformational change that rotates the myosin head from ~90° to ~45°, pulling the actin filament approximately 5-10 nm toward the M-line. ADP then releases, and the cycle repeats when new ATP binds (detaching myosin from actin). During contraction, the A-band (thick filament region) remains constant, the I-band (actin-only region) narrows, and the H-zone (myosin-only region in the center) narrows. Option B is incorrect because actin filaments do not shorten. Option A is wrong because thick filaments maintain constant length. Option D is incorrect because titin is a passive elastic element that provides resting tension, not an active motor.

questions.question: Lateral inhibition in sensory systems enhances edge detection and contrast. In the vertebrate retina, which cells are primarily responsible for mediating lateral inhibition?
options: Muller glial cells that provide structural support to the retina
Horizontal cells, which receive input from photoreceptors and provide inhibitory feedback to neighboring photoreceptors and feedforward inhibition to bipolar cells, sharpening spatial contrast
Ganglion cells that form the optic nerve
Retinal pigment epithelium cells that absorb stray light
questions.explanation: Lateral inhibition is a fundamental neural computation that enhances contrast at boundaries between differently illuminated regions. In the vertebrate retina, horizontal cells are the primary mediators of this process. Horizontal cells are interneurons in the outer plexiform layer that extend long lateral processes, receiving glutamatergic input from multiple photoreceptors across a wide area. They provide GABAergic (inhibitory) feedback to photoreceptor terminals and feedforward signals to bipolar cell dendrites. When a photoreceptor is strongly stimulated by light, it reduces glutamate release, which affects horizontal cells. The horizontal cells then modulate the responses of surrounding photoreceptors and bipolar cells, creating a center-surround receptive field organization. This means a bipolar cell responds best to a small spot of light (center) while being inhibited by illumination of the surrounding area. Amacrine cells in the inner plexiform layer provide a second level of lateral inhibition among bipolar and ganglion cells. Option A describes structural support cells. Option C describes output neurons. Option D describes non-neural cells.

questions.question: Electroreception is found in certain aquatic vertebrates. The ampullae of Lorenzini in sharks can detect electric fields as weak as 5 nV/cm. What is the physiological basis of this extraordinary sensitivity?
options: Sharks use piezoelectric crystals in their jaws to convert electric fields into mechanical vibrations
The ampullae contain voltage-gated potassium channels that amplify electric signals through positive feedback

The ampullae of Lorenzini are jelly-filled canals lined with electroreceptor cells containing voltage-gated Ca2+ channels with exceptionally low activation thresholds; the high-resistance jelly and low-resistance canal walls create a voltage divider that concentrates the external field across the receptor cell apical membrane
Sharks detect electric fields indirectly by sensing magnetic field distortions through magnetite crystals in their lateral line
questions.explanation: The ampullae of Lorenzini are among the most sensitive electroreceptors in the animal kingdom, capable of detecting fields as weak as 5 nV/cm. Each ampulla consists of a long jelly-filled canal (up to 20 cm) that opens to the skin surface and terminates in a cluster of electroreceptor cells. The canal jelly has very high electrical resistance (~5 MΩ·cm), while the canal walls have low resistance. This creates a voltage divider: the external electric field generates a potential difference primarily across the thin apical membranes of the receptor cells at the canal's blind end. The receptor cells contain voltage-gated Ca2+ channels with remarkably low activation thresholds. Even tiny voltage changes (~1 µV) across the apical membrane trigger Ca2+ influx, depolarization, and synaptic vesicle release onto afferent nerve fibers. The system achieves further sensitivity through electrical tuning and synaptic integration of multiple receptor cells. Option A is fabricated. Option B describes an incorrect mechanism. Option D confuses electroreception with magnetoreception.

questions.question: Motor unit recruitment follows the size principle described by Henneman. Which statement correctly describes this principle?
options: Large motor neurons with high conduction velocities are always recruited first for rapid movements
Motor units are recruited randomly to prevent fatigue

Motor neurons are recruited in order of increasing size — small motor neurons (innervating slow-twitch type I fibers) are recruited first at low force levels, and larger motor neurons (innervating fast-twitch type II fibers) are recruited progressively as greater force is needed
All motor units in a muscle are activated simultaneously during any voluntary contraction
questions.explanation: Henneman's size principle (1965) states that motor neurons are recruited in order of increasing cell body size during voluntary contraction. Small alpha motor neurons have higher input resistance and lower rheobase (threshold current), meaning they are excited by smaller synaptic currents. They innervate slow-twitch (type I) motor units — small numbers of fatigue-resistant oxidative fibers ideal for sustained postural activity. As the CNS increases excitatory drive to the motor neuron pool, progressively larger motor neurons reach threshold. Medium-sized neurons innervate fast-twitch oxidative-glycolytic (type IIa) fibers, and the largest neurons innervate fast-twitch glycolytic (type IIx/IIb) fibers capable of generating high force but fatiguing rapidly. This orderly recruitment provides smooth force gradation: fine control at low forces (small increments from small motor units) and powerful contractions when needed. De-recruitment follows the reverse order. Option A reverses the order. Option B is incorrect — recruitment is orderly, not random. Option D describes a tetanic pattern that does not normally occur.

questions.question: Tonotopic organization of the basilar membrane is fundamental to frequency discrimination in the mammalian cochlea. How does the basilar membrane achieve frequency selectivity?
options: All regions of the basilar membrane vibrate equally to all frequencies, and frequency discrimination is performed entirely in the auditory cortex

The basilar membrane varies in width and stiffness along its length — it is narrow and stiff at the base (near the oval window), resonating at high frequencies (~20 kHz), and wide and flexible at the apex (helicotrema), resonating at low frequencies (~20 Hz), creating a place code for frequency
Hair cells at different locations express different ion channel isoforms that are tuned to specific frequencies
The tectorial membrane selectively dampens specific frequencies before they reach the basilar membrane
questions.explanation: Georg von Bekesy's Nobel Prize-winning work demonstrated that the basilar membrane acts as a mechanical frequency analyzer through its graded physical properties. At the base, the membrane is approximately 0.1 mm wide and very stiff (high resonant frequency ~20 kHz). At the apex, it is ~0.5 mm wide and 100 times more compliant (low resonant frequency ~20 Hz). This gradient creates a tonotopic map: each location along the 35 mm length responds maximally to a specific 'characteristic frequency.' High-frequency sounds create maximum displacement near the base; low-frequency sounds peak near the apex. This passive tuning is sharpened approximately 100-fold by active amplification from outer hair cells, whose prestin-based electromotility provides cycle-by-cycle mechanical feedback. The resulting 'place code' means that the brain determines sound frequency by which auditory nerve fibers (connected to specific basilar membrane locations) are most active. Option A is incorrect because mechanical tuning occurs in the cochlea. Option C describes electrical tuning found in non-mammalian vertebrates. Option D misrepresents tectorial membrane function.

questions.question: The vestibular system detects head position and movement. Which structures specifically detect angular acceleration (rotational head movements)?
options: The cochlear duct, which is continuous with the vestibular apparatus
The utricle and saccule, which contain otoliths embedded in a gelatinous matrix

The three semicircular canals — rotation of the head causes endolymph flow that deflects the cupula in the ampulla, bending hair cell stereocilia and modulating firing rates in vestibular nerve afferents
Proprioceptors in the neck muscles that detect head rotation relative to the body
questions.explanation: The three semicircular canals (anterior, posterior, and horizontal/lateral) are specifically designed to detect angular acceleration in three orthogonal planes. Each canal contains endolymph and terminates in an expanded ampulla housing a crista — a ridge of hair cells topped by a gelatinous cupula. When the head rotates, inertia causes endolymph to lag behind, pushing against the cupula and deflecting hair cell stereocilia. Deflection toward the kinocilium increases the firing rate of vestibular afferents; deflection away decreases it. The three canals are oriented in approximately orthogonal planes, enabling detection of rotation in any direction. The canals work in push-pull pairs (e.g., left and right horizontal canals respond oppositely to the same rotation). In contrast, the utricle and saccule (Option B) detect linear acceleration and static head tilt using otoconia (calcium carbonate crystals) that slide over hair cells. Option A is incorrect — the cochlea is for hearing. Option D describes proprioception, not vestibular function.

questions.question: Olfactory receptor neurons in mammals use a cAMP-mediated signal transduction pathway. What makes olfactory receptor gene expression unique compared to other sensory receptor systems?
options: Each olfactory neuron expresses all ~400 (human) or ~1000 (mouse) odorant receptor genes simultaneously to maximize sensitivity
Olfactory receptors are ionotropic glutamate receptors rather than G-protein coupled receptors

Each olfactory sensory neuron expresses only one allele of one odorant receptor gene (the 'one neuron-one receptor' rule), and all neurons expressing the same receptor converge their axons onto the same glomerulus in the olfactory bulb, creating a spatial odor map
Olfactory receptor genes are expressed in the olfactory bulb rather than in the nasal epithelium
questions.explanation: The olfactory system exhibits a remarkable organizational principle discovered by Buck and Axel (Nobel Prize, 2004). The odorant receptor gene family is the largest in the mammalian genome (~1000 genes in mice, ~400 functional genes in humans). Each mature olfactory sensory neuron (OSN) expresses only one receptor gene from one allele — a process called 'monogenic and monoallelic expression' enforced by epigenetic mechanisms including the choice of a single enhancer element (a 'Greek island') from among many. This singular expression means each OSN is tuned to a specific set of odorants. Furthermore, all OSNs expressing the same receptor project their axons to the same 1-2 glomeruli in the ipsilateral olfactory bulb (convergence), creating a stereotyped glomerular map. Different odorants activate different combinations of receptors, and the brain interprets odor identity from this combinatorial pattern across glomeruli. Option A is wrong because only one receptor is expressed per neuron. Option B is incorrect — mammalian odorant receptors are GPCRs (though insects do use ionotropic receptors). Option D reverses the location.

questions.question: Muscle spindles are proprioceptors that detect changes in muscle length. The stretch reflex arc involves both sensory and motor components. What is the role of gamma motor neurons in this system?
options: Gamma motor neurons directly cause contraction of extrafusal muscle fibers to produce movement

Gamma motor neurons innervate the contractile polar regions of intrafusal muscle fibers, adjusting spindle sensitivity so that the spindle remains functional across the full range of muscle lengths — this alpha-gamma coactivation ensures continuous proprioceptive feedback during voluntary movement
Gamma motor neurons inhibit antagonist muscles during the stretch reflex via reciprocal inhibition
Gamma motor neurons transmit sensory information from the muscle spindle to the spinal cord
questions.explanation: Muscle spindles contain 6-8 intrafusal fibers (nuclear bag and nuclear chain fibers) enclosed in a connective tissue capsule, running parallel to the extrafusal (force-generating) fibers. The central (equatorial) region of intrafusal fibers is wrapped by Ia (primary) and II (secondary) sensory afferents that detect stretch. The polar (contractile) ends receive motor innervation from gamma motor neurons. When alpha motor neurons contract extrafusal fibers, the muscle shortens. Without gamma coactivation, the intrafusal fibers would go slack, rendering the spindle unable to detect further length changes — creating a 'sensory dead zone.' Gamma motor neurons solve this by simultaneously contracting the polar ends of intrafusal fibers, taking up the slack and maintaining spindle sensitivity throughout the range of movement. This alpha-gamma coactivation is a fundamental principle of motor control. Option A describes alpha motor neurons. Option C describes inhibitory interneurons (Ia inhibitory interneurons). Option D describes sensory afferents (Ia and II fibers).

questions.question: Color vision in humans is trichromatic, based on three types of cone photoreceptors. The opponent-process theory explains certain aspects of color perception. Which phenomenon is best explained by the opponent-process theory rather than trichromacy alone?
options: The ability to perceive millions of distinct colors through combinations of three cone types

Color afterimages — staring at a green image then looking at a white surface produces a red afterimage, because opponent channels (red-green, blue-yellow, black-white) undergo rebound excitation after adaptation
The reduced color discrimination in dim light conditions
Red-green color blindness caused by absence of medium-wavelength cone opsin
questions.explanation: The opponent-process theory, proposed by Ewald Hering and later confirmed neurophysiologically by Hurvich and Jameson, complements trichromatic theory by explaining post-retinal color processing. While trichromacy (Young-Helmholtz theory) explains that three cone types (S/blue ~420 nm, M/green ~530 nm, L/red ~560 nm) provide the initial basis for color vision, opponent processing explains how cone signals are recombined in retinal ganglion cells and the lateral geniculate nucleus into three opponent channels: red-green (L minus M), blue-yellow (S minus L+M), and luminance (L+M). Color afterimages arise because prolonged viewing of one color adapts (fatigues) one side of an opponent channel. When the stimulus is removed, the opposing channel rebounds, producing the complementary color perception. Staring at green adapts the green side of the red-green channel; the white surface then activates the red side more strongly, producing a red afterimage. Option A is explained by trichromacy alone. Option C relates to rod-cone transition. Option D is a genetic deficiency in cone opsin genes.

questions.question: The neuromuscular junction (NMJ) uses acetylcholine as its neurotransmitter. What is the role of acetylcholinesterase (AChE) at the NMJ, and what happens when it is inhibited?
options: AChE synthesizes acetylcholine; inhibiting it prevents neurotransmitter production and causes paralysis

AChE rapidly hydrolyzes ACh in the synaptic cleft into choline and acetate, terminating the signal; inhibition by nerve agents (e.g., sarin) or organophosphate pesticides causes sustained ACh activity, leading to continuous muscle stimulation, fasciculations, and potentially fatal paralysis of respiratory muscles
AChE transports ACh back into the presynaptic terminal for recycling
AChE is a postsynaptic receptor that binds ACh and generates the end-plate potential
questions.explanation: Acetylcholinesterase is one of the fastest enzymes known, with a turnover number of ~25,000 molecules/second. It is concentrated in the synaptic cleft at the NMJ, anchored to the basal lamina by a collagen-like tail (ColQ). AChE rapidly hydrolyzes acetylcholine into choline and acetate, ensuring that each nerve impulse produces a brief, discrete end-plate potential. The choline is recycled back into the presynaptic terminal via a high-affinity choline transporter (CHT1) and reused for ACh synthesis by choline acetyltransferase (ChAT). When AChE is inhibited — by organophosphates (sarin, VX, malathion), carbamates (neostigmine, pyridostigmine), or naturally by fasciculin from mamba venom — ACh accumulates in the synaptic cleft. This causes prolonged depolarization of the motor end plate, initial fasciculations followed by depolarization block, and ultimately flaccid paralysis. At muscarinic synapses (parasympathetic), AChE inhibition causes bradycardia, bronchospasm, excessive secretions, and miosis. Treatment involves atropine (muscarinic antagonist) and pralidoxime (AChE reactivator). Option A confuses AChE with ChAT. Option C describes a reuptake transporter. Option D describes the nicotinic ACh receptor.

questions.question: Echolocation in bats involves emission of ultrasonic pulses and analysis of returning echoes. What adaptation allows bats to hear faint echoes immediately after emitting loud pulses (~140 dB)?
options: Bats have exceptionally large pinnae that amplify returning echoes by 60 dB

The stapedius muscle contracts just before each pulse emission, attenuating middle ear transmission by ~20 dB (the acoustic reflex), and the tensor tympani contracts simultaneously, reducing self-stimulation; these muscles relax within milliseconds to detect the faint returning echoes
Bats process echoes using a separate auditory pathway that bypasses the cochlea entirely
Bat cochlear hair cells regenerate every few milliseconds to avoid damage from loud emissions
questions.explanation: Echolocating bats face a fundamental challenge: their emitted pulses can exceed 140 dB SPL (louder than a jet engine at close range), while returning echoes may be as faint as 0 dB SPL — a dynamic range of 140 dB. Several adaptations address this. The middle ear muscles (stapedius and tensor tympani) contract in precise synchrony with each pulse emission, stiffening the ossicular chain and attenuating sound transmission by ~20 dB. This contraction is neurally coupled to the motor commands generating the laryngeal pulse — the muscles contract ~5-10 ms before emission and relax within 2-8 ms afterward to detect echoes. Additional adaptations include: neural suppression circuits in the lateral lemniscus and inferior colliculus that inhibit response during emission, specialized delay-tuned neurons in the auditory cortex that respond to specific echo delays (encoding target distance), and Doppler-shift compensation neurons (in CF-FM bats like Rhinolophus) for velocity detection. Option A overestimates pinna amplification. Option C is anatomically impossible. Option D is incorrect — mammalian hair cells do not regenerate.

questions.question: Nociceptors are sensory neurons that detect potentially damaging stimuli. What molecular receptor is responsible for detecting capsaicin (the active compound in chili peppers) and noxious heat above 43°C?
options: TRPV1 (transient receptor potential vanilloid 1), a nonselective cation channel expressed on C-fiber and A-delta nociceptors that is activated by capsaicin, noxious heat (>43°C), low pH (<6.0), and certain lipid mediators like anandamide
Substance P receptor (NK1), a neuropeptide receptor on nociceptors
ASIC3 (acid-sensing ion channel 3), which responds exclusively to protons
Nav1.7, a voltage-gated sodium channel that generates action potentials in nociceptors
questions.explanation: TRPV1 was identified by David Julius (Nobel Prize, 2021) using an expression cloning strategy from a dorsal root ganglion cDNA library. TRPV1 is a polymodal nociceptor channel — a nonselective cation channel (permeable to Ca2+, Na+, and Mg2+) that integrates multiple noxious stimuli. Its activators include: (1) capsaicin and resiniferatoxin (vanilloid compounds), (2) noxious heat >43°C, (3) extracellular protons (pH <6.0), (4) endogenous lipids (anandamide, 12-HPETE), and (5) inflammatory mediators that sensitize the channel (bradykinin, prostaglandins, NGF lower its activation threshold). TRPV1 is expressed on small-diameter C-fiber and A-delta nociceptor cell bodies in dorsal root and trigeminal ganglia, with terminals in skin, viscera, and joints. Channel activation causes depolarization and action potential firing, perceived as burning pain. Prolonged capsaicin exposure paradoxically desensitizes TRPV1 through Ca2+-dependent mechanisms, explaining its use in topical analgesic creams. Option B is a neuropeptide receptor involved in central pain processing. Option C responds to acid but not capsaicin. Option D generates action potentials but does not transduce stimuli.

questions.question: Skeletal muscle fiber types differ in their metabolic and contractile properties. Which correctly matches muscle fiber type with its characteristics?
options: Type I (slow oxidative) fibers have high myoglobin content, dense mitochondria, and express MHC-I (beta-myosin heavy chain) with slow ATPase activity, making them fatigue-resistant and ideal for sustained postural maintenance and endurance activities
Type I fibers have the fastest contraction speed and highest glycolytic capacity
Type IIx fibers are the most fatigue-resistant and have the highest mitochondrial density
Type IIa fibers rely exclusively on anaerobic glycolysis and contain no mitochondria
questions.explanation: Mammalian skeletal muscle contains a spectrum of fiber types classified by myosin heavy chain (MHC) isoform expression. Type I (slow oxidative) fibers express MHC-I (beta-cardiac MHC), have slow cross-bridge cycling rates (~110 ms twitch duration), high mitochondrial density, high myoglobin content (giving them a red color), and predominantly oxidative metabolism. They have high capillary density and are extremely fatigue-resistant, making them ideal for sustained activities like postural maintenance and long-distance running. Type IIa (fast oxidative-glycolytic) fibers express MHC-IIa, contract faster (~50 ms), have intermediate mitochondrial density, and use both oxidative and glycolytic metabolism — moderately fatigue-resistant. Type IIx (fast glycolytic, called IIb in rodents) fibers express MHC-IIx, have the fastest contraction speed (~25 ms), lowest mitochondrial density, rely heavily on glycolysis, and fatigue rapidly but generate the highest peak power. Option B reverses Type I characteristics. Option C reverses Type IIx characteristics. Option D is wrong because Type IIa has significant oxidative capacity.

questions.question:
Match the following sensory receptor types with their adequate stimuli:
(I) Pacinian corpuscle
(II) Merkel cell-neurite complex
(III) Ruffini ending
(IV) Meissner's corpuscle

(P) Light touch and texture discrimination; slowly adapting type I mechanoreceptor with small receptive field
(Q) Deep pressure and vibration (60-300 Hz); rapidly adapting type II mechanoreceptor with large receptive field and lamellated structure
(R) Skin stretch and joint angle; slowly adapting type II mechanoreceptor with elongated fusiform shape
(S) Light flutter and low-frequency vibration (10-50 Hz); rapidly adapting type I mechanoreceptor in dermal papillae
options: I-Q, II-P, III-R, IV-S
I-P, II-Q, III-S, IV-R
I-R, II-S, III-Q, IV-P
I-S, II-R, III-P, IV-Q
questions.explanation: The glabrous (hairless) skin of the human hand contains four major mechanoreceptor types, classified by adaptation rate and receptive field size. Pacinian corpuscles (I-Q) are large (~1 mm), deeply located, rapidly adapting (RA-II) receptors with onion-like lamellae that act as a mechanical high-pass filter, making them exquisitely sensitive to vibration at 60-300 Hz (peak ~250 Hz) with large receptive fields. They detect tool vibrations and distant events. Merkel cell-neurite complexes (II-P) are slowly adapting type I (SA-I) receptors located at the epidermal-dermal junction with small, well-defined receptive fields — ideal for spatial resolution, texture discrimination, and form perception (e.g., reading Braille). Ruffini endings (III-R) are slowly adapting type II (SA-II) receptors with elongated fusiform capsules that respond to sustained skin stretch and lateral tension, contributing to finger position sense and grip control. Meissner's corpuscles (IV-S) are rapidly adapting type I (RA-I) receptors in the dermal papillae, sensitive to light touch and flutter vibration at 10-50 Hz (peak ~30 Hz) — important for detecting slip during object manipulation.

questions.question: The compound eye of insects differs fundamentally from the camera-type eye of vertebrates. What is the functional unit of a compound eye and how does it contribute to vision?
options: The functional unit is the ommatidium — each contains a corneal lens, crystalline cone, and photoreceptor cells (retinula cells with a central rhabdomere), and collectively the thousands of ommatidia create a mosaic image with each unit sampling one point in visual space, providing excellent motion detection but lower spatial resolution than camera eyes
The functional unit is a miniature retina with rods and cones identical to vertebrate photoreceptors
Compound eyes use a single large lens that projects an image onto a continuous photoreceptor sheet
Each unit of the compound eye functions independently with its own optic nerve and brain processing center
questions.explanation: Compound eyes, found in arthropods, consist of hundreds to tens of thousands of ommatidia (up to ~30,000 in dragonflies). Each ommatidium is a self-contained optical unit with: (1) a corneal lens (biconvex cuticular structure), (2) a crystalline cone (refractive focusing element), (3) 6-9 retinula cells whose rhabdomeres (microvillar stacks containing rhodopsin) form the light-sensing structure, and (4) pigment cells that optically isolate each ommatidium (in apposition compound eyes of diurnal insects) or allow light sharing (in superposition compound eyes of nocturnal insects like moths). Each ommatidium samples a small solid angle of visual space (~1-5°), and the brain integrates signals from all ommatidia to form a mosaic image. The interommatidial angle determines spatial resolution — typically 1-2° (compared to ~0.01° in the human fovea), so compound eyes have lower acuity. However, the high temporal resolution (~300 Hz flicker fusion vs. ~60 Hz in humans) and wide field of view (~360° in some species) provide superb motion detection. Option B incorrectly applies vertebrate photoreceptor terminology. Option C describes camera eyes. Option D overstates independence.

questions.question: Excitation-contraction (E-C) coupling in skeletal muscle involves the transmission of an electrical signal to trigger Ca2+ release. What is the molecular mechanism that couples T-tubule depolarization to sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ release?
options: Ca2+ enters through T-tubule L-type Ca2+ channels and triggers Ca2+-induced Ca2+ release from the SR, identical to cardiac muscle
T-tubule depolarization activates protein kinase A, which phosphorylates the ryanodine receptor to open it

Depolarization of T-tubule dihydropyridine receptors (DHPR/Cav1.1) causes a conformational change that is mechanically transmitted through direct protein-protein interaction to ryanodine receptors (RyR1) on the SR membrane, opening the RyR1 Ca2+ release channel without requiring Ca2+ influx through the DHPR
IP3 generated by phospholipase C activates IP3 receptors on the SR to release Ca2+
questions.explanation: Skeletal muscle E-C coupling is unique among muscle types in using mechanical (conformational) coupling rather than Ca2+-induced Ca2+ release (CICR). The dihydropyridine receptor (DHPR/Cav1.1) is a voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel located in the T-tubule membrane. In skeletal muscle, DHPR functions primarily as a voltage sensor rather than a Ca2+ channel — its II-III cytoplasmic loop directly contacts and activates the ryanodine receptor type 1 (RyR1) on the apposed SR terminal cisternae (junctional SR). DHPRs are arranged in tetrads that align with alternate RyR1 tetramers, forming organized junctions called triads. When an action potential propagates down the T-tubule, DHPR undergoes a voltage-dependent conformational change that mechanically opens RyR1, releasing Ca2+ from the SR lumen (where [Ca2+] ~1 mM) into the cytoplasm (raising [Ca2+] from ~50 nM to ~10 µM). This contrasts with cardiac muscle (Option A), where DHPR/Cav1.2 conducts Ca2+ that triggers CICR through RyR2. Option B describes a modulatory pathway. Option D describes smooth muscle signaling.

questions.question: Taste receptor cells on the tongue can detect five basic taste modalities. The umami taste detects the amino acid glutamate. What receptor mediates umami taste perception?
options: Epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) that also mediate salty taste
Ionotropic glutamate receptors (NMDA and AMPA types) identical to those in the brain

A heterodimer of T1R1 and T1R3 taste receptor subunits (T1R1+T1R3), which is a G-protein coupled receptor that signals through gustducin and phospholipase C-beta2, ultimately opening TRPM5 channels to depolarize the taste cell
T2R bitter taste receptors that cross-react with amino acids
questions.explanation: Umami taste ('pleasant savory taste') was identified as the fifth basic taste modality, distinct from sweet, salty, sour, and bitter. The primary umami receptor is a heterodimeric G-protein coupled receptor composed of T1R1 and T1R3 subunits (taste receptor type 1, members 1 and 3). This is related to but distinct from the sweet taste receptor (T1R2+T1R3, which shares the T1R3 subunit). When L-glutamate (or its salts like MSG) or 5'-ribonucleotides (IMP, GMP — which potentiate umami through allosteric modulation of T1R1+T1R3) bind the Venus flytrap domain of T1R1, the receptor activates the G-protein gustducin. Gustducin's beta-gamma subunit activates phospholipase C-beta2 (PLCβ2), generating IP3 and diacylglycerol. IP3 releases Ca2+ from intracellular stores, which activates the TRPM5 cation channel, depolarizing the taste cell. The depolarized cell releases ATP through CALHM1 channels as its neurotransmitter. Option B is partially true — mGluR1/mGluR4 contribute to umami, but the primary receptor is T1R1+T1R3. Option A mediates Na+ taste. Option D mediates bitter taste.

questions.question: An experiment measures the force output of a frog gastrocnemius muscle at different sarcomere lengths. Results show: at 1.6 µm, force is 40% of maximum; at 2.0 µm, force is 85%; at 2.2 µm, force is 100%; at 2.8 µm, force is 70%; at 3.6 µm, force is 0%. What explains the relationship between sarcomere length and force production?
options: The data reflect differences in neural activation patterns at different stretch levels
The relationship reflects ATP depletion at extreme sarcomere lengths
Force differences are due to changes in Ca2+ sensitivity of troponin at different muscle lengths

Force depends on the degree of overlap between thick and thin filaments — maximal force occurs at optimal overlap (~2.0-2.2 µm) where the maximum number of cross-bridges can form; force decreases at shorter lengths due to thin filament overlap and thick filament compression against Z-discs, and at longer lengths due to reduced cross-bridge formation as filaments pull apart
questions.explanation: The length-tension relationship of skeletal muscle, first precisely measured by Gordon, Huxley, and Julian (1966) using single frog muscle fibers, is a cornerstone prediction of the sliding filament theory. At the optimal sarcomere length (~2.0-2.2 µm in frog, ~2.6-2.8 µm in human), there is maximal overlap between thick filament cross-bridge regions and thin filaments, allowing the maximum number of myosin heads to engage actin. At this length, thin filaments extend from the Z-disc to the edge of the bare zone (H-zone center where no myosin heads exist). At longer sarcomere lengths (2.2→3.6 µm), thin filaments are pulled out from between thick filaments, progressively reducing the number of possible cross-bridges; at ~3.6 µm, there is zero overlap and zero active force. At shorter sarcomere lengths (<2.0 µm), force decreases because: (1) thin filaments from opposite sides overlap in the center, interfering with cross-bridge cycling, and (2) thick filaments compress against Z-discs. This data is experimental evidence directly supporting the cross-bridge model of contraction.

questions.question: Statocysts are gravity-sensing organs found in many invertebrates. How do statocysts function in organisms like crayfish?
options: Statocysts contain dense particles called statoliths (often sand grains) resting on mechanosensory hair cells; when the animal changes orientation relative to gravity, the statoliths shift and deflect different hair cells, providing information about body position
Statocysts detect sound vibrations in the water through resonance of their fluid-filled chambers
Statocysts use photoreceptor cells to detect the direction of light for orientation
Statocysts produce electrical signals that create an electromagnetic field around the organism for navigation
questions.explanation: Statocysts are found in cnidarians, mollusks, crustaceans, and other invertebrates. In crayfish (and other decapod crustaceans), statocysts are located at the base of the first antennae (antennules). Each consists of a fluid-filled chamber lined with sensory hair cells and containing dense particles (statoliths). In crayfish, the statoliths are actually sand grains that the animal must replace after each molt — this was elegantly demonstrated by Kreidl's classic experiment (1893), where crayfish offered iron filings instead of sand incorporated them into their statocysts, and their orientation could then be manipulated with magnets, proving the gravitational sensing mechanism. When the animal tilts, gravity causes the statoliths to shift, deflecting different populations of hair cells. The pattern of hair cell stimulation encodes the animal's orientation in three-dimensional space. The system is analogous in principle to the vertebrate utricle and saccule, which use otoconia (calcium carbonate crystals) instead of sand grains. Option B describes lateral line or auditory function. Option C describes photoreception. Option D is fabricated.

questions.question: Smooth muscle contraction differs from skeletal muscle in its regulatory mechanism. What is the primary pathway for initiating smooth muscle contraction?
options: Smooth muscle uses the same troponin-tropomyosin system as skeletal muscle

Ca2+-calmodulin activates myosin light chain kinase (MLCK), which phosphorylates the regulatory light chain of myosin II at Ser19, enabling myosin to bind actin and generate force — this is in contrast to the troponin-based thin filament regulation used in striated muscles
Smooth muscle contraction is initiated by direct mechanical stretch without any biochemical signaling
Smooth muscle uses titin as the primary contractile protein rather than actin and myosin
questions.explanation: Smooth muscle lacks the troponin complex found in striated (skeletal and cardiac) muscle. Instead, it uses a thick filament (myosin-based) regulatory mechanism centered on myosin light chain phosphorylation. When intracellular Ca2+ rises (from SR release via IP3 receptors and/or extracellular entry through L-type Ca2+ channels and receptor-operated channels), Ca2+ binds calmodulin (CaM). The Ca2+-CaM complex activates myosin light chain kinase (MLCK), which phosphorylates the 20 kDa regulatory light chain (RLC) of myosin II at Serine 19 (and sometimes Threonine 18). This phosphorylation activates myosin ATPase activity by relieving an autoinhibitory conformation, allowing cross-bridge cycling with actin. Relaxation requires dephosphorylation by myosin light chain phosphatase (MLCP). The RhoA/Rho-kinase pathway can inhibit MLCP (Ca2+ sensitization), maintaining contraction at lower Ca2+ levels. Smooth muscle can also maintain force with low energy expenditure through a 'latch state' involving dephosphorylated but still-attached cross-bridges. Option A is incorrect — smooth muscle lacks troponin. Option C ignores the biochemistry. Option D is wrong.

questions.question: The somatosensory cortex contains a topographic representation of the body surface called the somatotopic map (sensory homunculus). What principle explains why the hands and lips occupy disproportionately large cortical areas?
options: The cortical area devoted to a body region is proportional to the density of sensory receptors and the behavioral importance of that region — the hands and lips have extremely high mechanoreceptor density (up to 2,500 Meissner's corpuscles per cm2 in fingertips) requiring more cortical processing power for fine tactile discrimination
Hands and lips are physically larger than other body parts, so they occupy more cortical space
The expanded representation is an artifact of cortical folding patterns and has no functional significance
More cortical area is devoted to body regions that experience the most pain
questions.explanation: The somatosensory homunculus, mapped by Penfield and Boldrey (1937) using intraoperative electrical stimulation, reveals a distorted representation of the body in the primary somatosensory cortex (S1, postcentral gyrus). Body regions with high innervation density and high discriminative ability (low two-point discrimination threshold) are represented by proportionally larger cortical areas. The fingertips have a two-point discrimination threshold of ~2 mm and mechanoreceptor density of ~240 per cm2 (Meissner's + Merkel cells), while the back has a threshold of ~40 mm and much lower receptor density. This cortical magnification provides the computational substrate for fine tactile discrimination needed for skilled manipulation. The lips and tongue are similarly expanded, reflecting their importance in speech, eating, and social behavior. Importantly, the somatotopic map is plastic — it can reorganize following amputation (phantom limb), skill learning (string musicians have expanded finger representations), or sensory deprivation. Option B confuses physical size with sensory importance. Option C dismisses clear functional significance. Option D conflates pain processing with somatosensory representation.

questions.question: A researcher wants to determine whether a newly discovered protein in C. elegans is essential for mechanotransduction in touch receptor neurons. Which experimental approach would most directly test this hypothesis?
options: Measure the protein's mRNA levels in different tissues using RT-qPCR
Overexpress the protein in all neurons and observe general locomotion patterns

Perform a CRISPR knockout of the gene encoding the protein, then test the mutant worms for response to gentle body touch using an eyelash hair stimulus — compare touch sensitivity between knockout and wild-type worms, and perform rescue experiments by expressing the wild-type gene in touch receptor neurons under the mec-4 promoter
Crystallize the protein and determine its three-dimensional structure
questions.explanation: C. elegans is the premier model organism for studying mechanotransduction, with six touch receptor neurons (ALM, AVM, PLM, PVM pairs) identified by Chalfie and colleagues. The most direct approach to test whether a protein is essential for mechanotransduction combines loss-of-function and rescue experiments. Step 1: CRISPR/Cas9 knockout of the candidate gene creates a null mutant. Step 2: Touch sensitivity is assayed by stroking the worm with an eyelash hair mounted on a toothpick — wild-type worms reverse when touched anteriorly (ALM/AVM-mediated) or accelerate when touched posteriorly (PLM-mediated). The mec mutant phenotype is quantified as % non-responsive trials over 10 touches. Step 3: Rescue experiment — expressing the wild-type gene specifically in touch neurons using the mec-4 or mec-7 promoter confirms cell-autonomous function. Controls should include tissue-specific expression in non-touch neurons (should not rescue) and expression of a mutated form. Option B tests overexpression, not necessity. Option A shows expression but not function. Option D provides structure but not physiological role.

questions.question: Outer hair cells (OHCs) in the mammalian cochlea amplify sound vibrations through electromotility. Which protein is essential for this active amplification mechanism?
options: Prestin (SLC26A5), a motor protein in the OHC lateral membrane that changes its conformation in response to membrane potential changes, causing the cell to elongate and shorten at acoustic frequencies up to ~70 kHz, thereby amplifying basilar membrane vibrations by ~40-60 dB
Myosin VIIa, a molecular motor that transports vesicles in hair cells
Otoferlin, a Ca2+ sensor required for synaptic vesicle fusion at inner hair cell ribbon synapses
Connexin 26, a gap junction protein that recycles K+ in the cochlea
questions.explanation: Prestin (SLC26A5) is a member of the solute carrier 26 anion transporter family that has evolved a unique motor function in mammalian outer hair cells. Prestin is densely packed in the OHC lateral plasma membrane (~7,000 molecules per µm2). When the OHC depolarizes (during basilar membrane deflection toward scala vestibuli), prestin contracts, shortening the cell; when it hyperpolarizes, prestin elongates the cell. This electromotility occurs at acoustic frequencies (up to ~70 kHz in bats and ~20 kHz in humans) — far too fast for any known molecular motor or cytoskeletal mechanism. Prestin functions as an incomplete transporter whose anion-binding site (Cl- or HCO3-) acts as a voltage sensor, driving conformational changes that alter cell length by ~3-5%. This cochlear amplifier provides ~40-60 dB of gain, explaining why prestin knockout mice have ~40-60 dB hearing loss despite intact inner hair cells and auditory nerve. Option B is important for stereocilia organization but not electromotility. Option C mediates synaptic transmission. Option D is involved in K+ recycling; mutations cause deafness but not through motility.

questions.question: Magnetoreception allows certain animals to detect Earth's magnetic field for navigation. Which mechanism is best supported by evidence in migratory birds?
options: Birds detect magnetic fields through piezoelectric crystals in their beaks that generate voltage in response to field changes

Two complementary mechanisms have been proposed and supported: (1) a radical pair mechanism in cryptochrome proteins in the retina, where blue light generates radical pairs whose spin dynamics are influenced by magnetic field direction, and (2) magnetite-based receptors in the upper beak innervated by the trigeminal nerve that detect field intensity
Birds use the Coriolis force generated by Earth's rotation to determine latitude
Magnetic sensitivity arises from ferromagnetic hemoglobin in the blood that aligns with field lines
questions.explanation: Magnetoreception in birds involves at least two complementary systems. The radical pair mechanism, proposed by Schulten (1978) and supported by behavioral and molecular evidence, operates in cryptochrome proteins (Cry1a, Cry4) in the retina. Blue light excites a flavin-tryptophan radical pair in cryptochrome; the interconversion between singlet and triplet spin states is influenced by Earth's magnetic field (~50 µT), potentially providing directional (compass) information overlaid on visual perception. This system requires light (birds are disoriented in darkness), is disrupted by radiofrequency magnetic fields, and provides an inclination compass (detects field angle, not polarity). The second system uses magnetite (Fe3O4) crystals, likely in the upper beak region innervated by the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve (V1). This may provide magnetic map information (field intensity) for determining geographic position. Cutting the trigeminal nerve disrupts this sense but not the light-dependent compass. Option A fabricates a mechanism. Option C is physically incorrect. Option D is wrong — hemoglobin is paramagnetic when deoxygenated but far too weak for magnetoreception.

questions.question: The photoreceptor adaptation mechanism allows rod cells to function over a range of ~10^6 light intensities. What is the primary molecular mechanism of light adaptation in rods?
options: Light adaptation occurs solely by pupil constriction reducing light reaching the retina

Light-induced Ca2+ decrease activates recoverin, which inhibits rhodopsin kinase, and activates guanylate cyclase through GCAPs (guanylate cyclase-activating proteins), restoring cGMP levels and resetting CNG channel sensitivity — this Ca2+-dependent feedback adjusts the gain of the phototransduction cascade
Rhodopsin molecules are physically rotated to face away from incoming light
Rod cells switch from using transducin to using a different G-protein during bright light
questions.explanation: Light adaptation in rod photoreceptors is primarily mediated by Ca2+-dependent feedback mechanisms. In darkness, CNG channels conduct Ca2+ (and Na+) into the outer segment, maintaining cytoplasmic Ca2+ at ~500 nM. The Na+/Ca2+-K+ exchanger (NCKX) continuously exports Ca2+. During light, CNG channels close (reduced cGMP), but NCKX continues operating, causing a rapid decline in Ca2+ to ~50 nM. This Ca2+ decrease triggers three main adaptation mechanisms: (1) GCAPs (GCAP1/GCAP2) become active when Ca2+ falls, stimulating retinal guanylate cyclase (RetGC) to synthesize cGMP faster, partially restoring CNG channel current. (2) Recoverin releases rhodopsin kinase (GRK1) from inhibition, allowing faster phosphorylation and quenching of activated rhodopsin. (3) Ca2+ decrease increases the affinity of CNG channels for cGMP (through calmodulin dissociation). Together, these mechanisms shift the operating range of the rod, allowing it to respond to incremental light changes even at brighter background levels. Option A contributes minimally to photoreceptor-level adaptation. Option C is physically impossible. Option D is incorrect.

questions.question:
Match the following types of skeletal muscle contraction with their definitions:
(I) Isometric contraction
(II) Concentric contraction
(III) Eccentric contraction
(IV) Isokinetic contraction

(P) Muscle lengthens while generating tension, as when lowering a weight slowly — produces the highest forces per motor unit and is associated with delayed-onset muscle soreness
(Q) Muscle generates tension without changing length, as when holding a weight stationary — no external work is performed
(R) Contraction at a constant angular velocity throughout the range of motion, requiring specialized dynamometer equipment
(S) Muscle shortens while generating tension, as when lifting a weight — the force generated exceeds the external load
options: I-Q, II-S, III-P, IV-R
I-S, II-P, III-Q, IV-R
I-P, II-Q, III-R, IV-S
I-R, II-S, III-Q, IV-P
questions.explanation: Muscle contraction types are classified by the relationship between muscle tension and length change. Isometric contraction (I-Q): The muscle generates force without changing length — sarcomeres generate tension but the external load equals the muscle force, so no movement occurs. Examples include holding a heavy object stationary or maintaining posture. No mechanical work is done (W = F × d, where d = 0). Concentric contraction (II-S): The muscle shortens while generating tension — the internal force exceeds the external load, causing the muscle's insertion to move toward its origin. Examples include the biceps during a curl (lifting phase). Eccentric contraction (III-P): The muscle lengthens under tension — the external load exceeds the concentric force capacity. Cross-bridges are forcibly detached, generating ~1.5-1.8 times more force per cross-bridge than isometric or concentric contractions. Eccentric contractions cause more muscle damage (Z-disc streaming, sarcolemma disruption) and delayed-onset muscle soreness (DOMS). Isokinetic contraction (IV-R): Contraction at constant velocity throughout the range of motion, achievable only with specialized equipment (isokinetic dynamometers) that provides accommodating resistance.

questions.question: The lateral line system in fish and aquatic amphibians detects water movements. What is the functional sensory unit of the lateral line?
options: Pit organs that detect infrared radiation from warm-blooded prey
The ampulla of Lorenzini, which detects electrical fields generated by prey

The neuromast, containing mechanosensory hair cells with stereocilia and a kinocilium, embedded in a gelatinous cupula that is deflected by water flow — superficial neuromasts detect surface water movements while canal neuromasts respond to pressure gradients between canal pores
Photophores that detect bioluminescent signals from other fish
questions.explanation: The lateral line system is a mechanosensory organ unique to fish and aquatic amphibians (terrestrial amphibians lose it at metamorphosis). The functional unit is the neuromast, which contains 15-20 hair cells structurally similar to inner ear hair cells — each has a staircase of stereocilia and a single kinocilium. The cilia are embedded in a gelatinous cupula that protrudes into the water (superficial neuromasts) or into a fluid-filled canal (canal neuromasts). Water movement deflects the cupula, bending the stereocilia. Deflection toward the kinocilium depolarizes the hair cell; deflection away hyperpolarizes it. Superficial neuromasts detect water velocity (local flow over the body surface), while canal neuromasts respond to the pressure difference between adjacent canal pores — effectively detecting the spatial gradient of water pressure changes, making them sensitive to nearby moving objects. The lateral line enables schooling behavior, predator detection, prey localization, and rheotaxis (orientation to water currents). Option B describes electroreception, a separate system. Option A describes snake pit organs. Option D is fabricated.

questions.question: A researcher records receptor potentials from a Pacinian corpuscle using a microelectrode. When sustained pressure is applied, the receptor shows a large initial depolarization that rapidly decays to baseline within ~50 ms, even though pressure is maintained. When pressure is released, another transient depolarization occurs. What does this response pattern indicate about this receptor's classification?
options: The Pacinian corpuscle is a rapidly adapting (phasic) receptor — its lamellated structure acts as a mechanical high-pass filter that transmits only the onset and offset of a stimulus, making it optimally sensitive to vibration and transient stimuli rather than sustained pressure
The receptor is slowly adapting and the decay represents ion channel fatigue
The response pattern indicates the receptor is damaged and not functioning normally
The transient response shows the receptor can only detect painful stimuli
questions.explanation: The Pacinian corpuscle is the classic example of a rapidly adapting (phasic) mechanoreceptor. Its characteristic response pattern — strong onset and offset responses with rapid adaptation to sustained stimuli — is directly related to its unique structure. The corpuscle consists of 20-70 concentric lamellae (onion-like layers) separated by fluid-filled spaces surrounding a central nerve ending. When sustained pressure is applied, the lamellae redistribute the mechanical energy: the initial compression is faithfully transmitted to the central nerve ending, producing a receptor potential. However, within milliseconds, the viscoelastic lamellae redistribute stress so that the steady-state pressure is borne by the outer layers and is no longer transmitted to the nerve ending — the receptor potential decays. When pressure is released, the elastic rebound of the lamellae again mechanically stimulates the nerve ending, producing the 'off' response. Werner Loewenstein demonstrated this by removing the lamellae: the bare nerve ending becomes slowly adapting, responding throughout sustained pressure. This filtering makes Pacinian corpuscles optimally tuned for detecting vibration (peak sensitivity ~250 Hz), tool use vibrations, and textural information during active touch.

questions.question: Arthropod muscles differ from vertebrate muscles in several respects. Which statement correctly describes a unique feature of insect flight muscle?
options: Insect flight muscles use a completely different contractile protein system based on paramyosin instead of actin-myosin

Asynchronous (fibrillar) flight muscle in many insects (Diptera, Hymenoptera, Coleoptera) can oscillate at frequencies far exceeding the neural firing rate — a single nerve impulse activates the muscle, which then oscillates mechanically due to stretch activation (a delayed force increase following stretch), coupled with the resonant properties of the thorax
All insect flight muscles are identical to vertebrate skeletal muscle but simply contract faster
Insect flight muscles lack sarcomeres and generate force through a non-sliding mechanism
questions.explanation: Asynchronous (fibrillar) flight muscle is one of the most remarkable adaptations in the animal kingdom. Found in ~75% of flying insect species (including flies, bees, wasps, and beetles), this muscle type contracts at frequencies of 100-1000 Hz — far exceeding the maximum neural firing rate (~200 Hz). The mechanism relies on stretch activation: when one set of antagonistic flight muscles contracts, it deforms the thorax and stretches the opposing set. This stretch triggers a delayed activation of the stretched muscles (~5-10 ms delay), which then contract and stretch the first set, creating a self-sustaining oscillation. The flight frequency is determined by the mechanical resonant frequency of the thorax-wing system, not by neural input. Neural signals serve only to initiate and modulate (via Ca2+ levels and octopaminergic innervation) the oscillation. In contrast, synchronous flight muscles (found in dragonflies, locusts, butterflies) contract once per nerve impulse, limiting wing-beat frequency to ~25-50 Hz. The molecular basis involves troponin-C isoforms with reduced Ca2+ sensitivity that require stretch-induced conformational changes for full activation. Option A is wrong — they use actin-myosin. Option C ignores fundamental differences. Option D is incorrect.

questions.question: The visual pigment rhodopsin undergoes a series of conformational changes after absorbing a photon. What is the chromophore of rhodopsin and what happens to it upon photon absorption?
options: The chromophore is flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD), which undergoes reduction upon light absorption
The chromophore is chlorophyll a, which absorbs green light and transfers energy to transducin

The chromophore is 11-cis retinal, a vitamin A derivative covalently bound to Lys296 of opsin via a protonated Schiff base; photon absorption causes isomerization to all-trans retinal within ~200 femtoseconds, triggering conformational changes in opsin that activate the G-protein transducin
The chromophore is melanin, which absorbs UV light and protects the retina from damage
questions.explanation: Rhodopsin is the visual pigment of rod photoreceptors, consisting of the GPCR protein opsin (~40 kDa, 7 transmembrane helices) covalently bound to 11-cis retinal (a derivative of vitamin A/retinol) through a protonated Schiff base linkage to Lysine 296 in transmembrane helix 7. The absorption maximum of rhodopsin is ~498 nm (blue-green). Upon absorbing a single photon, 11-cis retinal isomerizes to all-trans retinal in ~200 femtoseconds — one of the fastest photochemical reactions known, with a quantum yield of ~0.67. This isomerization straightens the retinal molecule, pushing against the opsin binding pocket and triggering a series of conformational intermediates: photorhodopsin → bathorhodopsin → lumirhodopsin → metarhodopsin I → metarhodopsin II (the active form, R*). Metarhodopsin II activates the G-protein transducin (Gt) by catalyzing GDP→GTP exchange. Each R* can activate ~500 transducin molecules before being quenched by rhodopsin kinase phosphorylation and arrestin binding. All-trans retinal eventually dissociates and is recycled to 11-cis retinal in the retinal pigment epithelium (visual cycle). Option B names a plant pigment. Option A describes a different photoreceptor system. Option D describes a protective pigment.

questions.question: Cardiac muscle differs from skeletal muscle in several important aspects of excitation-contraction coupling. Which statement correctly distinguishes cardiac E-C coupling?
options: Cardiac muscle does not have T-tubules and relies entirely on surface Ca2+ channels
Cardiac muscle uses the identical mechanical coupling mechanism as skeletal muscle through DHPR-RyR direct physical interaction

Cardiac muscle uses Ca2+-induced Ca2+ release (CICR) — L-type Ca2+ channels (Cav1.2/DHPR) in T-tubules conduct Ca2+ into the cell upon depolarization, and this trigger Ca2+ activates ryanodine receptors (RyR2) on the SR, amplifying the Ca2+ signal approximately 10-fold for contraction
Cardiac muscle contraction is regulated by myosin phosphorylation, identical to smooth muscle
questions.explanation: Cardiac E-C coupling fundamentally differs from skeletal muscle in using Ca2+-induced Ca2+ release (CICR) rather than mechanical coupling. When the cardiac action potential reaches the T-tubule, it activates L-type Ca2+ channels (Cav1.2, also called cardiac DHPR). Unlike skeletal muscle Cav1.1 (which functions as a voltage sensor), cardiac Cav1.2 conducts substantial Ca2+ current (ICa,L) into the dyadic cleft — the ~15 nm gap between the T-tubule and SR junctional membrane. This 'trigger Ca2+' (~10-20 µM locally) binds to and opens RyR2 channels on the SR, releasing a much larger amount of SR Ca2+ into the cytoplasm. The gain of CICR is approximately 10-fold: trigger Ca2+ of ~10 µA produces ~100 µA equivalent of SR Ca2+ release. This amplification is graded — more trigger Ca2+ produces more SR release — which allows physiological modulation of contractile force (e.g., by beta-adrenergic signaling increasing ICa,L). Cardiac muscle DHPRs are NOT arranged in tetrads opposite RyR2 (unlike skeletal muscle). Option B incorrectly states mechanical coupling. Option A is wrong — ventricular cardiomyocytes have extensive T-tubules. Option D describes smooth muscle regulation.

questions.question: A scientist hypothesizes that a specific population of neurons in the barrel cortex of mice is necessary for whisker-guided texture discrimination. Which experimental approach would most rigorously test necessity?
options: Record neural activity from the barrel cortex during texture discrimination and show that these neurons respond to different textures

Use optogenetic silencing (e.g., expressing halorhodopsin or archaerhodopsin in the target population via Cre-dependent viral vectors) to reversibly inhibit the neurons during the discrimination task, comparing performance with light-on versus light-off trials within the same session, while controlling for light artifacts with opsin-negative littermates
Lesion the entire barrel cortex and test whether the mouse can still detect whisker contact
Stain the barrel cortex with cytochrome oxidase to visualize the barrel map
questions.explanation: Testing necessity requires demonstrating that removing or silencing a component impairs function. Optogenetic silencing provides the most rigorous approach because: (1) Temporal precision — inhibition can be restricted to specific task phases (stimulus presentation, decision period), avoiding compensatory reorganization that occurs with permanent lesions. (2) Reversibility — light-on vs. light-off trials in the same session control for day-to-day performance variability, motivation, and learning effects. (3) Cell-type specificity — Cre-dependent viral strategies (e.g., AAV-DIO-eNpHR3.0 in specific Cre-driver lines) limit silencing to defined populations. (4) Controls — opsin-negative littermates receiving identical light illumination control for non-specific effects (heating, visual distraction). The experimental design should include: bilateral silencing, graded difficulty levels, psychometric curve analysis, and histological verification of expression. Option A demonstrates correlation, not necessity (neurons could respond without being required). Option C lacks specificity — the entire cortex is destroyed. Option D is purely anatomical with no functional test.

questions.question: The Golgi tendon organ (GTO) monitors muscle tension. How does the GTO reflex differ from the muscle spindle stretch reflex?
options: The GTO produces a monosynaptic excitatory reflex that increases muscle contraction when tension is high

The GTO reflex is a disynaptic (Ib) inhibitory reflex — when muscle tension is excessive, Ib afferents from the GTO activate inhibitory interneurons that inhibit the alpha motor neuron of the same muscle (autogenic inhibition), causing relaxation and protecting the muscle-tendon unit from damage
The GTO and muscle spindle produce identical reflexes — both cause excitation of the homonymous muscle
The GTO only functions during passive stretch, not during active contraction
questions.explanation: Golgi tendon organs are encapsulated sensory receptors located at the muscle-tendon junction, arranged in series with extrafusal muscle fibers. They are innervated by large-diameter Ib afferent neurons. GTOs respond primarily to muscle tension (both active contraction and passive stretch), with high sensitivity — a single GTO can detect the tension generated by a single motor unit. When muscle tension increases, the collagen fibers in the GTO capsule compress the Ib nerve endings, generating action potentials. In the spinal cord, Ib afferents activate Ib inhibitory interneurons (disynaptic pathway) that inhibit alpha motor neurons of the homonymous muscle — this is autogenic (Ib) inhibition. Simultaneously, the Ib pathway excites alpha motor neurons of antagonist muscles (reciprocal excitation). This reflex serves as a protective mechanism against excessive muscle force, preventing tendon avulsion. It contrasts with the muscle spindle (Ia) stretch reflex, which is monosynaptic and excitatory: stretch activates the homonymous muscle to resist the stretch. The GTO reflex also contributes to smooth force control during voluntary movements. Option A describes the opposite of the actual reflex. Option C is incorrect — they produce opposite effects. Option D is wrong — GTOs are very sensitive during active contraction.

questions.question: Pit vipers (Crotalinae) can detect infrared radiation emitted by warm-blooded prey. What receptor mediates this ability?
options: Specialized photoreceptor cells containing a novel infrared-absorbing pigment
Rhodopsin molecules in the pit organ that are tuned to absorb infrared photons
Piezoelectric sensors in the pit membrane that detect pressure changes from infrared radiation

TRPA1, a thermosensitive TRP channel expressed in the pit organ membrane that is activated by radiant heat from warm objects at distances of up to 1 meter, with temperature sensitivity sufficient to detect changes as small as 0.003°C at the pit membrane surface
questions.explanation: The pit organ of crotaline snakes (pit vipers: rattlesnakes, copperheads, water moccasins) and some boid snakes (boas, pythons) is one of the most sensitive infrared detectors in nature. The pit is a cavity between the eye and nostril, containing a thin (15 µm) membrane richly innervated by trigeminal nerve endings. Gracheva et al. (2010) identified TRPA1 (transient receptor potential ankyrin 1) as the molecular infrared receptor. Snake TRPA1 has a dramatically lower thermal activation threshold (~28°C) compared to mammalian TRPA1 (~17°C for noxious cold). Infrared radiation from warm prey heats the pit membrane, and TRPA1 channels in the nerve endings detect temperature increases as small as 0.001-0.003°C. The spatial resolution is sufficient to create a thermal image that is integrated with visual information in the optic tectum (where both visual and infrared sensory maps are superimposed), allowing accurate strike targeting even in complete darkness. Rattlesnakes can detect a mouse at ~1 meter distance based on its infrared emission alone. Option B is incorrect — infrared is thermal, not photochemical. Option C fabricates a mechanism. Option A incorrectly proposes a photoreceptor-based system.

questions.question: The refractory period of muscle fibers determines the maximum rate of stimulation. How does the refractory period of cardiac muscle differ from skeletal muscle, and what is the physiological significance?
options: Cardiac muscle has no refractory period, which allows it to beat continuously
Cardiac and skeletal muscle have identical refractory periods
Skeletal muscle has a longer refractory period than cardiac muscle

Cardiac muscle has a much longer absolute refractory period (~250 ms) compared to skeletal muscle (~1-2 ms) due to its prolonged action potential plateau (phase 2); this long refractory period prevents tetanic contraction of the heart, which would be fatal because it would stop the rhythmic pumping cycle
questions.explanation: The refractory period is the time after an action potential during which another action potential cannot be generated (absolute refractory period) or requires a stronger-than-normal stimulus (relative refractory period). Skeletal muscle has a brief action potential (~2-5 ms) and short absolute refractory period (~1-2 ms), allowing high-frequency stimulation and tetanic contractions (temporal summation of twitches) for sustained force production. Cardiac muscle has a much longer action potential (~200-300 ms in ventricular myocytes) due to the prolonged plateau phase (phase 2), during which L-type Ca2+ channels maintain depolarization. The absolute refractory period (~250 ms) spans most of the contractile period. This means that by the time the cardiac cell can be re-stimulated, it has already nearly completed its contraction and begun relaxing. This prevents tetanus of cardiac muscle — if the heart were tetanized, it would stop filling with blood and ejecting it, causing circulatory collapse and death. The long refractory period also protects against re-entrant arrhythmias (though shortened refractory periods in disease states can predispose to them). Option B is incorrect. Option C reverses the relationship. Option A is wrong — cardiac muscle does have a refractory period.

questions.question: Proprioception provides awareness of body position without visual input. Which brain region is most critical for integrating proprioceptive information for motor coordination?
options: The basal ganglia, which exclusively control voluntary movement initiation
The primary visual cortex (V1), which processes visual information about body position
The hippocampus, which stores spatial memories for navigation

The cerebellum, which receives proprioceptive input via the dorsal and ventral spinocerebellar tracts, integrates it with motor commands (efference copies) from the cerebral cortex, and generates error correction signals to refine ongoing movements — damage causes ataxia (uncoordinated movement) without paralysis
questions.explanation: The cerebellum is the primary integrative center for proprioceptive processing and motor coordination. It receives massive proprioceptive input through two major pathways: the dorsal spinocerebellar tract (DSCT, carrying unconscious proprioception from the lower body via Clarke's nucleus) and the ventral spinocerebellar tract (VSCT, carrying spinal interneuron activity reflecting motor commands). Upper body proprioception reaches the cerebellum via the cuneocerebellar tract and rostral spinocerebellar tract. The cerebellum compares: (1) the intended movement (efference copy from the cerebral cortex, relayed through pontine nuclei to the cerebellar cortex) with (2) the actual movement (proprioceptive feedback). Any discrepancy generates error signals, transmitted through the deep cerebellar nuclei to the thalamus and motor cortex, correcting the ongoing movement in real-time. Cerebellar lesions produce characteristic signs: ataxia (incoordination), dysmetria (overshooting/undershooting targets), intention tremor, dysdiadochokinesis (inability to perform rapid alternating movements), and hypotonia — all without paralysis or sensory loss. Option B processes vision. Option C is for memory. Option A contributes to but does not exclusively control movement.

questions.question: The protein titin (connectin) is the largest known protein (~3.7 MDa) and spans half the sarcomere. What are its primary functions in skeletal muscle?
options: Titin provides passive elasticity to the sarcomere, acting as a molecular spring that resists excessive stretch and restores resting sarcomere length after contraction; it also centers the thick filament in the sarcomere and contributes to the passive tension component of the length-tension relationship
Titin is the primary ATP-hydrolyzing motor protein that drives cross-bridge cycling
Titin serves exclusively as a scaffold for thin filament assembly and has no mechanical role
Titin functions only during embryonic muscle development and is degraded in adult tissue
questions.explanation: Titin (also known as connectin) is a giant protein (~34,000 amino acids, ~3.0-3.7 MDa depending on isoform) that extends from the Z-disc to the M-line, spanning half the sarcomere. In the A-band region, titin is bound to the thick filament surface, providing structural stability. In the I-band region, titin acts as a molecular spring with two main elastic elements: (1) tandem immunoglobulin (Ig) domains that unfold at low-moderate stretch, and (2) the PEVK region (rich in Pro, Glu, Val, Lys) that extends at higher stretch forces. This provides passive tension that increases exponentially with sarcomere length, preventing over-extension. The spring properties vary between muscle types through alternative splicing — cardiac titin (N2B isoform) is stiffer than skeletal titin (N2A isoform). Titin also: (a) centers the thick filament in the sarcomere through its M-line anchoring, (b) contains a kinase domain near the M-line that may serve as a mechanosensor, and (c) provides a template for thick filament assembly during myofibrillogenesis. Mutations in titin cause dilated cardiomyopathy and limb-girdle muscular dystrophy. Option B describes myosin. Option C is too narrow. Option D is wrong — titin is abundant in adult muscle.

questions.question: In an experiment on the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR), a subject wears prism goggles that reverse the visual field left-to-right. Initially, head turns produce inappropriate eye movements (VOR drives eyes in the wrong direction relative to the reversed visual field). After 1 week of wearing the goggles, the VOR adapts and produces appropriate compensatory eye movements. When the goggles are removed, the VOR is again inappropriate for several hours before readapting. What does this experiment demonstrate about the VOR?
options: The VOR is a fixed, hardwired reflex that cannot be modified by experience

The experiment demonstrates cerebellar-dependent motor learning — the cerebellum (specifically the flocculus) uses visual error signals (retinal slip) to recalibrate the VOR gain and direction over days, representing a form of supervised learning where climbing fiber inputs from the inferior olive convey the error signal to modify parallel fiber-Purkinje cell synapses
The adaptation occurs entirely in the vestibular nerve and does not involve the brain
The reversed VOR is caused by changes in semicircular canal fluid dynamics rather than neural plasticity
questions.explanation: VOR adaptation is one of the best-studied examples of cerebellar motor learning. The VOR normally generates compensatory eye movements opposite to head rotation, stabilizing gaze. Its gain (eye velocity/head velocity) must be precisely calibrated — the cerebellum performs this calibration using visual feedback. In the prism experiment (first performed by Ivo Kohler, later studied by Miles and Lisberger): (1) Prisms reverse the visual consequence of VOR eye movements, creating retinal image slip (visual error). (2) The flocculus of the cerebellum detects this error through climbing fiber input from the inferior olive, which receives retinal slip information from the accessory optic system. (3) Over days, climbing fibers drive long-term depression (LTD) at parallel fiber-Purkinje cell synapses in the flocculus, modifying Purkinje cell output to adapt VOR gain and even reverse its direction. (4) When goggles are removed, the adapted VOR is now inappropriate, and re-adaptation occurs through the same mechanism. This demonstrates that the VOR is continuously recalibrable through cerebellar-dependent supervised learning. Flocculus lesions abolish VOR adaptation while preserving the baseline VOR. Option A contradicts the experimental result. Option C ignores central processing. Option D proposes an impossible peripheral mechanism.

questions.question: Muscle fatigue during sustained high-intensity exercise has multiple contributing factors. Which factor is now considered the primary cause of fatigue during short-duration maximal exercise?
options: Accumulation of inorganic phosphate (Pi) from ATP and creatine phosphate hydrolysis is now considered the primary cause — Pi reduces cross-bridge force production by rebinding to the actomyosin-ADP complex, reduces Ca2+ sensitivity of the myofilaments, and precipitates with Ca2+ in the SR lumen, reducing Ca2+ release
Lactic acid accumulation is the sole cause of all types of muscle fatigue
Depletion of ATP to near-zero levels causes immediate rigor
Fatigue is entirely a central nervous system phenomenon with no peripheral muscle component
questions.explanation: The understanding of muscle fatigue has shifted significantly from the traditional 'lactic acid hypothesis.'
