While acidosis (from lactate/H+ accumulation) was long blamed, studies at physiological temperature show minimal effects of pH 6.5-7.0 on cross-bridge function. Instead, inorganic phosphate (Pi) accumulation is now considered the dominant peripheral fatigue factor during high-intensity exercise. During maximal exercise, creatine phosphate (CrP) is rapidly hydrolyzed: CrP + ADP → Cr + ATP (creatine kinase). Then ATP → ADP + Pi (myosin ATPase). Cytoplasmic Pi can rise from ~1 mM to 30-40 mM. This elevated Pi: (1) directly reduces cross-bridge force by 10-50% by reversing the Pi-release step of the cross-bridge cycle (rebinding to the actomyosin-ADP state), (2) reduces myofibrillar Ca2+ sensitivity, shifting the force-pCa curve rightward, (3) enters the SR and precipitates with Ca2+ as calcium-phosphate, reducing free SR Ca2+ available for release and thereby reducing the Ca2+ transient amplitude. ATP depletion (Option C) is rarely significant in vivo due to metabolic regulation. Option D ignores substantial peripheral mechanisms. Option B oversimplifies — lactate is actually an important fuel substrate.

questions.question: The retinal processing of visual information involves ON and OFF pathways. What determines whether a bipolar cell is ON-center or OFF-center?
options: ON bipolar cells express the metabotropic glutamate receptor mGluR6, which causes hyperpolarization when glutamate binds (via a Gαo-mediated cascade); since photoreceptors release more glutamate in darkness, ON bipolar cells are inhibited in darkness and depolarize when light reduces glutamate release — OFF bipolar cells express ionotropic AMPA/kainate receptors and depolarize when glutamate is present (darkness)
ON and OFF bipolar cells receive input from different photoreceptor types — ON from rods and OFF from cones
The distinction is determined by the position of the bipolar cell relative to the optic disc
ON bipolar cells have more dendrites than OFF bipolar cells, allowing them to collect more light
questions.explanation: The ON/OFF distinction in the retina is one of the most elegant signal processing mechanisms in neuroscience, determined entirely by the type of glutamate receptor expressed on the bipolar cell dendrites. Photoreceptors continuously release glutamate in darkness (tonic release) and reduce release when illuminated (they hyperpolarize to light). OFF bipolar cells express ionotropic glutamate receptors (AMPA and kainate types) that depolarize when glutamate binds — thus they are depolarized (active) in darkness and hyperpolarized by light onset (sign-conserving synapse). ON bipolar cells express the metabotropic receptor mGluR6 (GRM6), which activates the G-protein Gαo. In darkness, glutamate binding activates Gαo, which keeps the TRPM1 cation channel closed — the ON bipolar cell is hyperpolarized. When light reduces glutamate release, mGluR6 is no longer activated, TRPM1 opens, and the ON bipolar cell depolarizes (sign-inverting synapse). This creates parallel ON and OFF processing channels that converge onto ON and OFF ganglion cells, eventually reaching distinct layers (4Cα, 4Cβ) in the LGN and V1. Mutations in mGluR6 or TRPM1 cause complete congenital stationary night blindness. Option B incorrectly links receptor type to ON/OFF. Options C and D are fabricated.

questions.question: Troponin and tropomyosin regulate contraction in striated muscle. What specific roles do the three troponin subunits play?
options: All three troponin subunits bind Ca2+ independently to regulate different aspects of contraction

Troponin is a three-subunit complex: TnC (troponin C) binds Ca2+, TnI (troponin I) inhibits actin-myosin interaction by holding tropomyosin in the blocking position, and TnT (troponin T) anchors the troponin complex to tropomyosin — when Ca2+ binds TnC, conformational changes release TnI from actin, allowing tropomyosin to shift and expose myosin-binding sites on actin
Troponin subunits function identically and are interchangeable
Troponin directly hydrolyzes ATP to provide energy for the conformational change in tropomyosin
questions.explanation: The steric blocking model of striated muscle regulation involves the cooperative action of tropomyosin and the troponin complex on the thin filament. Each tropomyosin molecule spans 7 actin monomers and exists in three positions: blocked (B-state), closed (C-state), and open (M-state). The troponin complex (one per tropomyosin) has three subunits with distinct functions: (1) TnC (18 kDa): the Ca2+ sensor, containing EF-hand motifs. Cardiac TnC has one functional regulatory Ca2+-binding site (site II), while skeletal TnC has two (sites I and II). Ca2+ binding (Kd ~1-2 µM) triggers a conformational change that exposes a hydrophobic patch. (2) TnI (21-24 kDa): the inhibitory subunit that normally binds to actin and holds tropomyosin in the blocking position (B-state), preventing myosin binding. When TnC binds Ca2+, TnI's hydrophobic switch region is pulled away from actin toward TnC. (3) TnT (31-36 kDa): the anchoring subunit with an extended N-terminal tail that binds along tropomyosin, transmitting the conformational change. Ca2+-induced TnI release allows tropomyosin to shift from B→C→M states, progressively exposing myosin-binding sites. Cardiac TnI and TnT are clinical biomarkers for myocardial infarction. Option A is incorrect. Option C ignores distinct functions. Option D is wrong — no ATP is needed.

questions.question: Invertebrate eyes show remarkable diversity. The mirror eye of the scallop (Pecten) uses a fundamentally different optical principle from lens-based eyes. How does it form images?
options: Scallop eyes form images using diffraction gratings made of chitin layers
Scallop eyes use compound eyes identical to insects

Scallop eyes use a concave mirror (the argentea, composed of guanine crystals) behind the retina to reflect and focus light onto the photoreceptor layer — this is analogous to a reflecting telescope, in contrast to the refracting (lens-based) optics of camera eyes
Scallop eyes have no optical focusing mechanism and detect only light intensity
questions.explanation: The scallop (Pecten maximus) has up to 200 remarkable eyes, each ~1 mm in diameter, arranged along the mantle edge. Land (1965) and Palmer et al. (2017) showed that the primary image-forming structure is not the lens (which is present but underpowered) but rather a concave mirror — the argentea — located behind the double-layered retina. The argentea is composed of 20-30 alternating layers of guanine crystals and cytoplasm, with spacing tuned to reflect light of ~500 nm wavelength (a biological multilayer reflector, analogous to a Bragg mirror). The concave shape focuses reflected light onto the distal retina, which contains ciliary photoreceptors (using a hyperpolarizing response like vertebrate photoreceptors). A proximal retina with rhabdomeric photoreceptors (microvillar, depolarizing) also exists. Recent work by Palmer et al. showed the guanine crystals are precisely square-shaped and tiled to minimize optical aberrations — a remarkable example of biological materials engineering. This is the only known biological concave mirror imaging system, analogous in principle to a Newtonian reflecting telescope. Option B is wrong. Option A fabricates a mechanism. Option D underestimates scallop eye function.

questions.question: Central pattern generators (CPGs) are neural circuits that produce rhythmic motor outputs. Which property best characterizes CPGs?
options: CPGs require continuous sensory feedback to generate any rhythmic output

CPGs can produce rhythmic motor patterns in the absence of sensory input or descending commands from the brain — they are intrinsic spinal or brainstem circuits whose rhythm is generated by pacemaker neurons and reciprocal inhibition between half-center oscillators, though sensory feedback modulates their output
CPGs are located exclusively in the motor cortex and require conscious effort to maintain
CPGs generate only constant-frequency outputs that cannot be modulated by any input
questions.explanation: Central pattern generators are neural circuits capable of producing coordinated, rhythmic motor patterns without rhythmic sensory input or supraspinal commands. This was demonstrated by Thomas Graham Brown (1911) and later by Wilson (1961, locust flight) and Grillner (1985, lamprey swimming). Key properties: (1) Endogenous rhythmicity — CPGs generate rhythmic output even in isolated spinal cord preparations (fictive locomotion). This involves pacemaker neurons with intrinsic oscillatory properties (persistent Na+ current, Ih current) and/or network oscillation through reciprocal inhibition between flexor and extensor half-centers. (2) Pattern generation — CPGs coordinate multi-joint, multi-limb movements with appropriate phasing. (3) Modulability — while CPGs can generate basic patterns autonomously, sensory feedback (from proprioceptors, cutaneous receptors) shapes the output to adapt to terrain, obstacles, and perturbations. Descending commands from the mesencephalic locomotor region (MLR) initiate and control speed. Neuromodulators (serotonin, dopamine, norepinephrine) alter CPG frequency, amplitude, and pattern. Examples include locomotion, respiration, mastication, and swallowing CPGs. Option A is incorrect. Option C mislocates CPGs. Option D ignores modulation.

questions.question: The cochlear implant bypasses damaged hair cells to restore hearing. What is the fundamental principle of how a cochlear implant works?
options: The implant regenerates damaged hair cells using stem cell technology

An electrode array inserted into the scala tympani stimulates different regions of the auditory nerve according to the tonotopic map — a sound processor decomposes sound into frequency bands and delivers corresponding electrical pulses to the appropriate electrodes, exploiting the brain's place coding for pitch perception
The implant amplifies sound to extremely high levels that can stimulate remaining hair cells
A vibrating device attached to the skull bone stimulates the auditory cortex through bone conduction
questions.explanation: Cochlear implants are the most successful neural prosthetic to date, having restored hearing to over 1 million individuals. The device consists of: (1) an external sound processor (microphone + digital signal processor) worn behind the ear that decomposes incoming sound into ~12-22 frequency bands, (2) a transmitter coil that sends information transcutaneously to (3) an implanted receiver-stimulator, which delivers electrical pulses to (4) an electrode array threaded into the scala tympani. The array has 12-22 electrode contacts spaced along its length. Because the cochlea is tonotopically organized (high frequency at base, low frequency at apex), electrodes at the basal end stimulate high-frequency nerve fibers while apical electrodes stimulate low-frequency fibers. The brain interprets the pattern of stimulation as sound. Modern devices achieve ~80% open-set sentence recognition in quiet. Limitations include poor pitch resolution (22 electrodes vs. ~3,500 inner hair cells), difficulty in noise, and reduced music appreciation. Option A describes a future therapy not yet clinically available. Option C describes a hearing aid, not an implant. Option D describes a bone-anchored hearing aid.

questions.question:
Match the following visual system structures with their primary functions:
(I) Lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN)
(II) Superior colliculus
(III) Primary visual cortex (V1)
(IV) Inferotemporal cortex (IT)

(P) Object recognition and face perception through hierarchical processing along the ventral stream
(Q) Thalamic relay that segregates retinal input into magnocellular and parvocellular channels and transmits to V1
(R) Orientation-selective neurons that extract edges and spatial frequency, organized into ocular dominance and orientation columns
(S) Controls saccadic eye movements and integrates visual, auditory, and somatosensory spatial information
options: I-Q, II-S, III-R, IV-P
I-R, II-P, III-S, IV-Q
I-S, II-Q, III-P, IV-R
I-P, II-R, III-Q, IV-S
questions.explanation: The visual system processes information through a hierarchical series of brain structures. LGN (I-Q): The lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus is the primary relay between retina and cortex, organized into 6 layers. Layers 1-2 (magnocellular) receive input from parasol ganglion cells and process motion and coarse form. Layers 3-6 (parvocellular) receive from midget ganglion cells and process color and fine detail. The LGN receives massive corticogeniculate feedback modulating transmission based on attention. Superior colliculus (II-S): A midbrain structure with a retinotopic map in superficial layers and multimodal integration in deeper layers. It commands saccadic eye movements through burst neurons projecting to brainstem gaze centers. Primary visual cortex/V1 (III-R): Contains orientation-selective neurons discovered by Hubel and Wiesel, organized into ocular dominance columns and orientation hypercolumns. Simple cells respond to oriented bars at specific positions; complex cells are position-invariant. Inferotemporal cortex (IV-P): End stage of the ventral pathway, containing neurons selective for complex objects, faces (fusiform face area), and categories.

questions.question: Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease affecting the neuromuscular junction. What is the primary pathological mechanism?
options: Autoantibodies against acetylcholinesterase prevent ACh degradation

Autoantibodies (primarily IgG) against the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor cause receptor internalization and complement-mediated destruction of the postsynaptic membrane, reducing functional AChR numbers and decreasing the end-plate potential below threshold for muscle fiber action potential generation
Autoantibodies destroy the presynaptic motor nerve terminal, preventing ACh release
Autoantibodies against myosin heavy chain directly prevent muscle contraction
questions.explanation: Myasthenia gravis (MG) is the prototypical autoimmune channelopathy, caused by antibodies against the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (nAChR) at the neuromuscular junction in ~85% of cases. Three pathogenic mechanisms operate: (1) Antigenic modulation — anti-AChR antibodies cross-link adjacent receptors, accelerating their endocytosis and lysosomal degradation (receptor half-life decreases from ~5 days to ~1 day). (2) Complement activation — IgG1 and IgG3 anti-AChR antibodies fix complement, generating the membrane attack complex that destroys the postsynaptic membrane folds, reducing total membrane area and AChR density. (3) Direct functional block — some antibodies directly inhibit ACh binding. The result is reduced nAChR density (from ~10,000 to ~3,000 per µm2), simplified postsynaptic folds, and widened synaptic cleft. The safety factor of neuromuscular transmission (normally ~4x) is reduced below threshold, causing fluctuating weakness that worsens with activity. Treatment includes AChE inhibitors (pyridostigmine), immunosuppression, plasmapheresis, and thymectomy. In ~10% of cases, antibodies target MuSK instead. Option A reverses the target enzyme. Option C describes a different mechanism. Option D targets the wrong protein.

questions.question: Mantis shrimp (stomatopods) have 16 types of spectral photoreceptors. What additional visual capability do they uniquely possess among animals?
options: Mantis shrimp have echolocation capabilities similar to dolphins
Mantis shrimp can see X-rays emitted by deep-sea hydrothermal vents

Mantis shrimp can detect circularly polarized light — rows 5-6 of their midband contain quarter-wave retarder structures in the rhabdoms that convert circular polarization to linear polarization detectable by the aligned microvilli, a capability not found in any other known animal
Mantis shrimp can detect neutrinos from the sun using specialized photoreceptors
questions.explanation: Stomatopods possess the most complex visual system known in the animal kingdom. Their compound eyes have a distinctive midband of 6 rows of specialized ommatidia. Rows 1-4 contain 8 types of photoreceptors covering UV to far-red (~300-720 nm), including 4 UV types using different filtering pigments (mycosporine-like amino acids). Most remarkably, rows 5-6 detect both linearly and circularly polarized light. Linear polarization detection is common in arthropods (using aligned microvilli in rhabdomeres), but circular polarization detection is unique to stomatopods. The mechanism involves quarter-wave retarder structures within the rhabdom that convert circularly polarized light to linearly polarized light, which the aligned microvilli can then detect. Chiou et al. (2008) demonstrated this capability behaviorally. The biological function may include species-specific signaling — some stomatopod body parts selectively reflect circularly polarized light, creating a private communication channel invisible to predators. This represents a form of visual communication analogous to encrypted signals. Option B is physically impossible for biological photoreceptors. Options C and D are fabricated capabilities.

questions.question: Nuclear bag and nuclear chain fibers are the two main types of intrafusal fibers in muscle spindles. How do their sensory responses differ?
options: Nuclear chain fibers detect velocity while nuclear bag fibers detect static length
Both fiber types respond identically to stretch with no functional difference

Nuclear bag fibers (especially dynamic bag1 fibers) are innervated by Ia primary afferents and show strong dynamic sensitivity — they fire rapidly during the velocity of stretch (phasic response), providing information about how fast the muscle is lengthening; nuclear chain fibers are innervated primarily by group II secondary afferents and signal static muscle length with minimal velocity sensitivity
Nuclear bag fibers are sensory while nuclear chain fibers are exclusively motor
questions.explanation: Muscle spindles contain two functionally distinct types of intrafusal fibers that provide complementary proprioceptive information. Nuclear bag fibers (2-3 per spindle) are larger with nuclei clustered in a central equatorial bulge. There are two subtypes: dynamic bag1 fibers and static bag2 fibers. The Ia primary afferent wraps around the equatorial region of both bag and chain fibers in an annulospiral ending. Ia afferents from bag1 fibers show strong dynamic sensitivity — they fire at high rates proportional to the velocity of stretch (dL/dt), providing rapid feedback about movement speed. This is crucial for the dynamic stretch reflex. Nuclear chain fibers (4-8 per spindle) are thinner, with nuclei arranged in a single chain. Group II secondary afferents form flower-spray endings primarily on chain fibers and static bag2 fibers, providing tonic (position) information proportional to current muscle length. Gamma motor neurons differentially control spindle sensitivity: dynamic gamma neurons innervate bag1 fibers (enhancing velocity sensitivity) and static gamma neurons innervate bag2 and chain fibers (enhancing length sensitivity). This dual system provides the CNS with both derivative (velocity) and proportional (position) proprioceptive signals. Option B ignores clear functional distinctions. Option A reverses the roles. Option D incorrectly assigns motor function to chain fibers.

questions.question: To determine whether electric fish can discriminate object shape using their active electrosensory system, which experimental design would be most appropriate?
options: Record from electroreceptors while presenting metal objects of different shapes

Train weakly electric fish in a two-alternative forced choice paradigm to distinguish shapes using only their EOD, while controlling for non-electric cues by conducting trials in darkness with objects of identical volume and material but different geometry, and verify performance drops to chance when the electric organ is silenced
Observe whether electric fish swim toward or away from different shaped objects
Measure the EOD waveform while presenting shapes and look for discharge frequency changes
questions.explanation: Active electrolocation in weakly electric fish generates an electric field through their electric organ discharge (EOD), and objects create field perturbations detected by electroreceptors. To rigorously demonstrate shape discrimination: (1) Use operant conditioning with a two-alternative forced choice paradigm — the fish learns to approach one shape for a food reward. This provides quantitative discrimination measurement. (2) Control for confounds — objects must have identical material (same conductivity), identical volume (same amplitude disturbance), and be at identical distances. Objects should differ only in geometry. Darkness eliminates visual cues. Non-conducting partitions prevent lateral line detection. (3) Critical control — temporarily silencing the EOD (using curare to paralyze the electric organ). If performance drops to chance, this confirms electrosensory-dependent discrimination. (4) Neural recording (Option A) shows encoding but not behavioral discrimination. Option C lacks experimental control. Option D measures motor output rather than perceptual discrimination. Von der Emde demonstrated that Gnathonemus petersii can discriminate complex shapes and even 3D object properties using active electrolocation.

questions.question: SERCA is essential for muscle relaxation. What is the stoichiometry of SERCA-mediated Ca2+ transport?
options: SERCA transports Ca2+ out of the cell across the plasma membrane
SERCA passively allows Ca2+ to flow down its concentration gradient into the SR
SERCA transports 10 Ca2+ per ATP hydrolyzed through a channel-like mechanism

SERCA transports 2 Ca2+ ions into the SR lumen per ATP hydrolyzed, undergoing E1-to-E2 conformational transitions — the E1 state has high Ca2+ affinity facing the cytoplasm, while phosphorylation at Asp351 triggers a transition to E2 with low affinity facing the lumen, releasing Ca2+ against a 10,000-fold concentration gradient
questions.explanation: SERCA (sarco/endoplasmic reticulum Ca2+-ATPase) is a P-type ATPase (~110 kDa) that pumps 2 Ca2+ ions into the SR lumen per ATP hydrolyzed, lowering cytoplasmic Ca2+ from ~10 µM (contracted state) to ~50 nM (relaxed state). The mechanism follows the E1-E2 Albers-Post cycle, elucidated structurally by Toyoshima: E1 state — two Ca2+ bind to high-affinity sites (Kd ~0.1 µM) in the transmembrane domain from the cytoplasm, then ATP binds. E1-P — gamma-phosphate transfers to Asp351, forming a phosphoenzyme intermediate, occluding Ca2+. E2-P — conformational change reorients binding sites to face the SR lumen with reduced affinity (Kd ~1 mM), releasing Ca2+ against a ~10,000-fold gradient. Counter-transport of 2-3 H+ occurs. E2 to E1 — dephosphorylation returns pump to starting state. SERCA accounts for ~50% of resting muscle ATP consumption. In cardiac muscle, SERCA2a is inhibited by phospholamban (PLN) in its unphosphorylated form. Beta-adrenergic stimulation phosphorylates PLN via PKA, relieving inhibition and accelerating relaxation (lusitropy). Option B ignores active transport requirement. Option C vastly overestimates efficiency. Option A confuses SERCA with PMCA (plasma membrane Ca2+-ATPase).

questions.question: TRPM8 is the principal receptor for cool temperature sensation. What compounds also activate this channel, and what therapeutic applications does this have?
options: TRPM8 is activated by glucose and functions as a metabolic sensor
TRPM8 is activated only by capsaicin and has no pharmacological applications
TRPM8 responds exclusively to mechanical stimuli and cannot be activated by chemicals

TRPM8 is activated by menthol (the cooling compound in mint), icilin (a synthetic supercooling agent), and eucalyptol — this channel opens at temperatures below ~26°C and is expressed on A-delta and C-fiber thermoreceptors; TRPM8 agonists produce analgesic effects in neuropathic pain models, and the channel is a therapeutic target for pain management
questions.explanation: TRPM8 was identified by McKemy, Neuhausser, and Julius (2002) as the principal molecular sensor for cool temperatures. It is a nonselective cation channel activated by: (1) Cool temperatures below ~26°C (increasing activity down to ~10°C). (2) Menthol — the monocyclic terpene in mint that produces the characteristic cooling sensation (EC50 ~80 µM). (3) Icilin — a synthetic compound ~200x more potent than menthol. (4) Eucalyptol (1,8-cineole) from eucalyptus oil. (5) Other cooling agents: WS-3, WS-23 (used in the food industry). TRPM8 is expressed in ~10-15% of DRG and trigeminal neurons, primarily small-diameter A-delta and C-fibers. TRPM8 knockout mice show impaired behavioral responses to cool temperatures and menthol. Therapeutically, TRPM8 is a promising analgesic target: TRPM8 agonists produce pain relief in several neuropathic pain models, potentially through activation of descending inhibitory pathways. Menthol-containing topical preparations have been used empirically for pain relief for centuries. TRPM8 antagonists are being explored for cold allodynia (pathological cold pain). Option B confuses with TRPV1. Option C ignores chemical activation. Option A is fabricated.

questions.question: The power stroke in the myosin cross-bridge cycle is triggered by which specific event?
options: ATP hydrolysis while myosin is detached from actin generates the power stroke
ATP binding to the myosin head initiates the power stroke

Release of inorganic phosphate (Pi) from the myosin head while bound to actin triggers the lever arm conformational change — the lever arm swings from the pre-power stroke position (~90°) to the post-power stroke position (~45°), generating ~5-10 nm displacement and ~2-4 pN force per cross-bridge
Elastic recoil of the myosin tail generates force, not the head domain
questions.explanation: The myosin II cross-bridge cycle involves four main steps. The power stroke is specifically triggered during step 4 by Pi release: (1) Rigor state — myosin tightly bound to actin, no nucleotide. ATP binding causes rapid actin dissociation. (2) Recovery stroke — ATP hydrolysis (ATP to ADP+Pi, both remain bound) while myosin is detached reprimes the lever arm to the pre-power stroke (~90°) cocked position. (3) Weak binding — myosin-ADP-Pi rebinds weakly to actin on the adjacent thin filament. (4) Power stroke — Pi release triggers the lever arm swing from ~90° to ~45°, pulling the thin filament toward the M-line. Each cross-bridge generates ~5-10 nm displacement and ~2-4 pN force. ADP release follows, returning to rigor. The Lymn-Taylor model (1971) first proposed this kinetic cycle. Structural studies by Rayment et al. revealed the motor domain architecture. The lever arm (containing the essential and regulatory light chains) acts as an amplifier, converting small conformational changes in the motor domain active site into the ~10 nm displacement observed. The duty ratio (fraction of cycle time spent bound and generating force) is ~0.05 for skeletal muscle myosin II. Option B causes dissociation. Option A describes the recovery stroke. Option D misidentifies the force generator.

questions.question: The dorsal column-medial lemniscal pathway transmits fine touch and proprioception. What is the correct three-neuron relay sequence from receptor to cortex?
options: Receptor → DRG → spinal cord dorsal horn → hypothalamus → prefrontal cortex
Receptor → DRG → dorsal columns (fasciculus gracilis/cuneatus) → dorsal column nuclei in the medulla → medial lemniscus (decussation) → VPL nucleus of thalamus → primary somatosensory cortex (S1)
Receptor → DRG → spinothalamic tract → reticular formation → motor cortex
Receptor → ventral root → lateral spinothalamic tract → thalamus → visual cortex
questions.explanation: The dorsal column-medial lemniscal (DCML) pathway is the major ascending pathway for discriminative touch, vibration, two-point discrimination, and conscious proprioception. The three-neuron chain: First-order neuron — the pseudounipolar DRG neuron whose central process ascends ipsilaterally in the dorsal columns. Lower body (below T6) fibers travel in the fasciculus gracilis (medial); upper body fibers in the fasciculus cuneatus (lateral). Second-order neuron — located in the dorsal column nuclei (nucleus gracilis for lower body, nucleus cuneatus for upper body) in the caudal medulla. Their axons cross the midline as internal arcuate fibers and ascend as the medial lemniscus. Third-order neuron — located in the ventral posterolateral (VPL) nucleus of the thalamus, projecting through the internal capsule to S1 (Brodmann areas 3a, 3b, 1, 2 of the postcentral gyrus). Key features include high spatial fidelity, preserved somatotopy at every relay, and fast conduction in large myelinated fibers (30-70 m/s). Lesions at different levels produce characteristic deficits: ipsilateral below the lesion for spinal cord damage, contralateral for brainstem and above. Option A has wrong relay stations. Option C describes the anterolateral system. Option D has multiple errors.

questions.question: EMG recordings during a bicep curl show lower amplitude during the lowering (eccentric) phase compared to the lifting (concentric) phase, despite the same weight being controlled. What explains this finding?
options: EMG electrodes cannot reliably detect eccentric muscle activity
The muscle is completely relaxed during lowering and gravity alone controls the movement

Eccentric contractions generate more force per active motor unit than concentric contractions because forcibly detached cross-bridges contribute resistive force and titin provides passive tension during lengthening — therefore fewer motor units need to be recruited to support the same load, producing lower EMG amplitude
The antagonist triceps muscle controls the entire lowering phase
questions.explanation: This classic observation highlights the mechanical efficiency of eccentric contractions. During concentric contraction (shortening/lifting), each cross-bridge generates force only during its power stroke. During eccentric contraction (lengthening/lowering), multiple mechanisms increase force per active motor unit: (1) Forcibly detached cross-bridges — as the muscle is externally stretched, attached cross-bridges resist being pulled apart, each contributing ~1.5-1.8 times more force than during concentric or isometric contractions. (2) Titin's passive elasticity contributes resistive force during lengthening, especially at longer sarcomere lengths. (3) Residual force enhancement — muscle generates more isometric force after eccentric stretch compared to the same length reached by shortening. Because each active motor unit generates greater force eccentrically, the CNS recruits fewer motor units to control the same load. Since surface EMG amplitude primarily reflects the sum of motor unit action potentials (number of active units multiplied by their firing rates), fewer recruited units means lower EMG. This explains why eccentric exercise causes disproportionate muscle damage (high force per fiber) despite lower neural activation. Option B is wrong — the muscle is actively controlling descent. Option A is a technical error. Option D oversimplifies.

questions.question: Ribbon synapses in hair cells enable sustained, graded neurotransmitter release. What protein primarily constitutes the synaptic ribbon?
options: RIBEYE, an alternatively spliced form of the transcription factor CtBP2 — the synaptic ribbon tethers hundreds of vesicles near the active zone, supporting vesicle replenishment rates of 100-700 vesicles per second and enabling graded release proportional to receptor potential over a wide dynamic range
Synaptophysin, the same protein found at all conventional synapses
Bassoon, a large scaffolding protein identical at ribbon and conventional synapses
Synaptobrevins (VAMPs) that form the ribbon through self-assembly
questions.explanation: Ribbon synapses are specialized for sustained, graded neurotransmitter release in sensory receptor cells including photoreceptors, hair cells, and retinal bipolar cells. The defining structure is the synaptic ribbon (dense body): an electron-dense, plate-like structure (200-400 nm) anchored at the active zone. The major structural protein is RIBEYE, comprising an A-domain unique to synapses and a B-domain identical to CtBP2 (C-terminal binding protein 2, normally a transcriptional corepressor). RIBEYE self-assembles through A-domain interactions. The ribbon tethers 100-600 vesicles in a halo arrangement. Functionally: (1) The ribbon acts as a vesicle conveyor belt, delivering vesicles to release sites at rates exceeding conventional synapses (up to 700 vesicles/second at inner hair cell ribbons). (2) This supports sustained release proportional to the graded receptor potential — essential because hair cells and photoreceptors do not fire action potentials. (3) The readily releasable pool (~20 docked vesicles) allows rapid onset responses. (4) Multivesicular release increases dynamic range. Each inner hair cell has 10-20 ribbons, each contacting a single auditory nerve fiber. While Bassoon (Option C) is present and anchors the ribbon, it is not the primary structural component. Option B and D are not ribbon-specific.

questions.question: Catch muscle in bivalve mollusks can maintain tension for hours with minimal ATP consumption. What protein is responsible for this mechanism?
options: An exceptionally slow myosin isoform with a 100% duty ratio
A specialized tropomyosin that permanently blocks cross-bridge detachment
Collagen fibers that become rigid when electrically stimulated

Twitchin, a giant protein kinase — in the catch state, dephosphorylated twitchin forms long-lasting cross-links between paramyosin-containing thick filaments and actin thin filaments, maintaining tension without continuous cross-bridge cycling; release requires serotonin-stimulated phosphorylation by PKA
questions.explanation: Catch muscle in bivalve mollusks (mussels, clams, scallops) enables these animals to keep their shells closed for extended periods with minimal energy cost. The catch state maintains tension at ~10% of peak active force with ATP consumption ~200-fold lower than during active contraction. The molecular basis involves twitchin, a ~530 kDa protein related to titin that contains a C-terminal kinase domain. The mechanism: (1) Initial Ca2+-dependent contraction activates conventional actin-myosin cross-bridge cycling through direct Ca2+ binding to the essential light chain of myosin (molluscan thick filament regulation). (2) When Ca2+ is removed, cross-bridges detach but dephosphorylated twitchin forms stable cross-links between paramyosin-rich thick filaments and actin thin filaments. (3) These twitchin cross-links maintain tension as a mechanical latch without ATP hydrolysis. (4) Release requires serotonin signaling: 5-HT activates adenylyl cyclase, increasing cAMP, which activates PKA. PKA phosphorylates twitchin at multiple sites, reducing its actin/paramyosin binding affinity and releasing the catch. Funabara et al. showed recombinant twitchin fragments bind actin in a phosphorylation-dependent manner. Option B is incorrect. Option C misidentifies the element. Option A proposes an unrealistic mechanism.

questions.question: The retina processes visual information through two synaptic layers. How many synaptic relays exist in the direct vertical pathway before signals reach ganglion cells?
options: Five sequential synaptic relays process information before reaching ganglion cells
Visual information passes directly from photoreceptors to ganglion cells without synapses

Two synaptic relays: photoreceptors to bipolar cells in the outer plexiform layer (OPL), and bipolar cells to ganglion cells in the inner plexiform layer (IPL) — horizontal cells modulate laterally in the OPL while ~30 types of amacrine cells modulate in the IPL, enabling computations like direction selectivity and motion detection
Photoreceptors project directly to the brain without retinal processing
questions.explanation: The retina contains a remarkably efficient neural circuit arranged in three nuclear layers separated by two synaptic plexiform layers. The direct vertical pathway involves just two synaptic relays: First relay (OPL): Photoreceptors release glutamate from their synaptic terminals onto bipolar cell dendrites. Rod photoreceptors synapse onto rod bipolar cells at ribbon synapses. Cone photoreceptors synapse onto ~13 types of cone bipolar cells. Horizontal cells provide lateral GABAergic inhibition at this level, mediating center-surround receptive field organization. Second relay (IPL): Bipolar cell axon terminals synapse onto retinal ganglion cell dendrites, also at ribbon synapses. The IPL is subdivided into ON (sublamina b, inner) and OFF (sublamina a, outer) layers. Approximately 30 types of amacrine cells modulate transmission here, including: starburst amacrine cells for direction selectivity, AII amacrine cells for routing rod signals into cone pathways, and dopaminergic amacrine cells for light adaptation. Despite only two synaptic relays in the vertical pathway, the retina computes direction selectivity, object motion vs. global motion, contrast adaptation, and predictive coding before information leaves the eye. Option B and D ignore retinal processing. Option A overstates the relay number.

questions.question: Weber's Law describes a fundamental psychophysical principle. What does it state about the relationship between stimulus intensity and the just noticeable difference (JND)?
options: The JND is a constant proportion of the original stimulus intensity (ΔI/I = k) — meaning as background intensity increases, a proportionally larger absolute change is needed for detection, which holds across most sensory modalities with different Weber fractions (e.g., ~2% for weight, ~5% for sound intensity, ~8% for light brightness)
The JND is a fixed absolute value regardless of stimulus intensity
The JND decreases as stimulus intensity increases
Weber's Law applies only to the visual system
questions.explanation: Weber's Law (Ernst Heinrich Weber, 1834) is one of the most fundamental and general principles in psychophysics. It states that the smallest detectable change in a stimulus (JND or difference threshold) is a constant fraction of the reference stimulus. Mathematically: ΔI/I = k, where ΔI = JND, I = background intensity, k = Weber fraction (constant for a given modality). Examples: weight discrimination k ≈ 0.02 (2%), so a 100 g JND is ~2 g, but 1 kg JND is ~20 g. Sound intensity k ≈ 0.05, light brightness k ≈ 0.08, salt concentration k ≈ 0.08. The law holds remarkably well over ~2 log units of stimulus intensity for nearly all modalities, deviating only at very low intensities (near absolute threshold) and very high intensities. Fechner extended this to his logarithmic law: S = k × ln(I/I₀), predicting that perceived magnitude grows logarithmically with physical intensity. Stevens later proposed a power law: S = k × I^n. The biological basis involves logarithmic receptor potential encoding, neural adaptation, gain control mechanisms, and population coding in sensory cortex. Option B describes absolute threshold, not JND. Option C is wrong — JND increases in proportion. Option D incorrectly limits scope.

questions.question: To map V1 receptive fields in a cat, what experimental approach did Hubel and Wiesel pioneer?
options: fMRI scanning while showing the cat visual stimuli and measuring BOLD signal changes

Inserting a microelectrode into V1 to record single-unit extracellular action potentials while systematically presenting oriented bars of light at different positions, orientations, and movement directions — mapping which stimuli maximize firing rate to classify cells as simple (distinct ON/OFF subregions) or complex (orientation-selective but position-invariant)
Staining V1 with cytochrome oxidase to visualize cortical columns and infer function
Recording EEG from the scalp over the occipital lobe
questions.explanation: Hubel and Wiesel's Nobel Prize-winning approach (1959-1981) used single-unit extracellular microelectrode recording in V1 of anesthetized, paralyzed cats. Their method: (1) Insert a tungsten microelectrode into V1 and isolate single-neuron action potentials using amplitude discrimination. (2) Project visual stimuli (bars, edges, spots of light) onto a tangent screen while monitoring spike rate via audio speaker and oscilloscope. (3) Systematically vary stimulus parameters: position in visual field, orientation (0-180°), direction of movement, spatial frequency, and eye of presentation. (4) Map the receptive field — the visual field region where stimuli modulate firing. Their key discoveries: Simple cells in layer 4 have distinct elongated ON and OFF subregions, responding best to oriented bars at precise positions (linear spatial summation). Complex cells (layers 2/3, 5/6) are orientation-selective but position-invariant within a larger receptive field, responding well to moving bars. End-stopped cells respond to bars of specific length. They discovered the columnar architecture: orientation columns, ocular dominance columns, and ice-cube model of V1 organization. Option A was not available in the 1960s. Option C is anatomical only. Option D lacks cellular resolution.

questions.question: Calsequestrin is the major Ca2+-binding protein in the SR lumen. What unique property allows it to store large amounts of Ca2+?
options: Calsequestrin binds 40-50 Ca2+ ions per molecule with moderate affinity (Kd ~1 mM) and polymerizes in a Ca2+-dependent manner near junctional SR, creating a concentrated Ca2+ reservoir while maintaining free luminal Ca2+ at ~1 mM to reduce osmotic stress — it also regulates RyR gating through interactions with triadin and junctin
Calsequestrin has a single high-affinity Ca2+-binding site like calmodulin
Calsequestrin is a membrane protein that pumps Ca2+ into the SR using ATP
Calsequestrin is located in the cytoplasm and prevents Ca2+ from reaching the myofilaments
questions.explanation: Calsequestrin (CSQ) is a luminal SR protein uniquely adapted for high-capacity Ca2+ storage. Skeletal CSQ1 (~63 kDa) and cardiac CSQ2 (~45 kDa) share key features: (1) High-capacity binding — each molecule binds 40-50 Ca2+ ions, primarily through clusters of acidic residues (Asp, Glu) on the protein surface. The binding affinity is moderate (Kd ~1 mM), allowing rapid Ca2+ association and dissociation during the contraction-relaxation cycle. (2) Ca2+-dependent polymerization — at physiological luminal Ca2+ concentrations (>0.5 mM), CSQ monomers assemble into linear polymers via front-to-front and back-to-back stacking. These polymers localize near the junctional SR face, concentrating stored Ca2+ adjacent to RyR channels. Total SR Ca2+ can reach 20-30 mM while free Ca2+ remains ~1 mM, minimizing osmotic load. (3) RyR regulation — CSQ interacts with RyR1/RyR2 through anchor proteins triadin and junctin embedded in the SR membrane. When luminal Ca2+ drops, CSQ depolymerizes and conformational changes propagate through triadin/junctin to inhibit RyR opening, preventing complete SR depletion. CSQ2 mutations cause CPVT, a lethal cardiac arrhythmia syndrome. Option B underestimates capacity. Option C confuses with SERCA. Option D mislocates the protein.

questions.question: The majority of corticospinal axons decussate at which anatomical location?
options: The anterior commissure of the spinal cord at every segment
The optic chiasm in the diencephalon
The corpus callosum connecting the cerebral hemispheres

The pyramidal decussation in the caudal medulla — approximately 85-90% of corticospinal fibers cross here to form the lateral corticospinal tract in the contralateral spinal cord, while ~10-15% continue ipsilaterally as the anterior corticospinal tract, crossing at segmental levels to innervate axial muscles
questions.explanation: The corticospinal tract (CST) originates from motor cortex (M1, ~30%), premotor areas (~30%), SMA (~20%), and S1 (~20%). Axons descend through the corona radiata, posterior limb of internal capsule, cerebral peduncle, and basis pontis, forming the medullary pyramids. At the cervicomedullary junction, approximately 85-90% of fibers undergo the pyramidal decussation — crossing the midline — to descend contralaterally as the lateral corticospinal tract (LCST) in the lateral funiculus. The LCST primarily controls distal limb muscles and monosynaptically contacts motor neurons for fine digit movements (unique to primates). The remaining 10-15% descend ipsilaterally as the anterior corticospinal tract (ACST), which crosses at segmental levels via the anterior white commissure, primarily innervating bilateral axial and proximal muscles. Clinical significance: lesions above the pyramidal decussation produce contralateral hemiplegia with upper motor neuron signs. Lesions below produce ipsilateral weakness. The pyramidal decussation explains why the right motor cortex controls the left body and vice versa. Option B is the site of visual fiber crossing. Option C connects cerebral hemispheres. Option A occurs only for the ACST component.

questions.question: Creatine kinase catalyzes a critical reaction for energy buffering in muscle. What is the reaction and why is it important during the first seconds of maximal exercise?
options: Creatine kinase synthesizes creatine from arginine and glycine

Creatine kinase reversibly transfers phosphate from phosphocreatine to ADP (PCr + ADP → Cr + ATP), buffering ATP levels during the first 5-10 seconds of maximal exercise — this phosphagen system responds faster than glycolysis or oxidative phosphorylation, maintaining ATP at ~5 mM while PCr drops from ~25 mM to near zero
Creatine kinase converts glucose to glucose-6-phosphate
Creatine kinase breaks down ATP to produce heat for thermogenesis
questions.explanation: Creatine kinase (CK) catalyzes: PCr + ADP + H+ ⇌ Cr + ATP. This near-equilibrium reaction provides the fastest mechanism for ATP regeneration in muscle. At rest, skeletal muscle PCr concentration is ~25-35 mM (vs. ATP at ~5 mM), representing a readily mobilized energy reserve. During the onset of maximal exercise, ATP consumption can increase 100-fold instantaneously. Glycolysis requires ~5-10 seconds to fully activate; oxidative phosphorylation takes ~2-3 minutes. The CK reaction regenerates ATP within milliseconds, maintaining cellular [ATP] nearly constant while [PCr] falls. This phosphagen system powers the first ~5-10 seconds of all-out effort (100 m sprint, vertical jump, shot put). Additional CK functions include: spatial energy buffering via the CK shuttle (mitochondrial mi-CK produces PCr from mitochondrial ATP; cytoplasmic MM-CK regenerates ATP at myofibrils, effectively transporting energy faster than ATP diffusion), and H+ buffering (the forward reaction consumes a proton, partially countering exercise-induced acidosis). There are tissue-specific isoforms: MM (skeletal muscle), MB (cardiac), BB (brain), and mi-CK (mitochondrial). CK-MB elevation is a biomarker for myocardial infarction. Option A describes creatine biosynthesis. Option C describes hexokinase. Option D describes uncoupling.

questions.question: A neuroscientist records from a retinal ganglion cell with a center-surround receptive field. When a small spot of light illuminates only the center, the cell fires strongly. When light covers the entire receptive field (center + surround), the response is much weaker. When only the surround is illuminated, the cell is inhibited. What type of ganglion cell is this, and what neural mechanism creates the surround inhibition?
options: This is an ON-center ganglion cell — the surround inhibition is mediated primarily by horizontal cells in the outer plexiform layer, which receive input from a wide area of photoreceptors and provide inhibitory (GABAergic) feedback, creating an antagonistic surround that suppresses the center response when both are illuminated uniformly
This is an OFF-center cell that responds to darkness in the center
The surround response is an artifact of electrode placement and has no biological significance
This cell type is found only in invertebrate visual systems
questions.explanation: This is a classic ON-center/OFF-surround retinal ganglion cell — the most common type in the primate retina. The center-surround receptive field organization is fundamental to visual processing, enhancing contrast and edge detection. Mechanism: The center response arises from the direct photoreceptor → ON bipolar cell → ganglion cell pathway. Light in the center hyperpolarizes photoreceptors (reducing glutamate), which depolarizes ON bipolar cells (via mGluR6 sign-inverting synapse), which excites the ganglion cell. The surround is created primarily by horizontal cells, large interneurons in the outer plexiform layer that integrate input from many photoreceptors over a wide area. When the surround is illuminated, horizontal cells reduce their inhibitory output to the center-pathway bipolar cells, effectively opposing the center's excitation. When both center and surround are uniformly illuminated, the two signals partially cancel, producing a weak response. This center-surround antagonism means the cell responds best to spatial contrast (edges) rather than uniform illumination — a key feature for visual processing. Amacrine cells contribute additional surround inhibition in the inner plexiform layer. OFF-center cells show the opposite pattern. Option B reverses the polarity. Options C and D are incorrect.

questions.question: Retinal ganglion cells can be classified as M-type (magnocellular) and P-type (parvocellular). How do their functional properties differ?
options: P-type cells process motion while M-type cells process color
M-type and P-type cells are functionally identical and differ only in cell body size

M-type (parasol) ganglion cells have large receptive fields, high temporal resolution, and are sensitive to motion and contrast but are color-blind; P-type (midget) ganglion cells have small receptive fields, low temporal resolution, and encode color (red-green opponency) and fine spatial detail — they project to separate layers of the LGN
M-type cells project to the superior colliculus while P-type cells project to the inferior colliculus
questions.explanation: The M and P pathways represent two major parallel processing streams in primate vision, originating at the ganglion cell level. M-type (parasol) ganglion cells (~10% of ganglion cells) have large cell bodies, thick axons (fast conduction), large dendritic fields, and large receptive fields. They respond transiently to stimuli, have high contrast sensitivity (respond to ~2% contrast), and excellent temporal resolution but poor spatial resolution and are achromatic. They project to magnocellular layers 1-2 of the LGN, then to layer 4Cα of V1, feeding the dorsal (where/how) stream for motion processing and spatial relationships. P-type (midget) ganglion cells (~80% of ganglion cells) have smaller cell bodies, thinner axons, small dendritic fields, and small receptive fields. In the central retina, each midget ganglion cell receives input from a single cone (via a single midget bipolar cell), providing the highest possible spatial resolution. They show sustained responses, color opponency (red-green via L vs M cone antagonism), and lower contrast sensitivity. They project to parvocellular layers 3-6 of the LGN, then to layer 4Cβ, feeding the ventral (what) stream. A third pathway (koniocellular) processes blue-yellow color information.

questions.question: The enzyme acetylcholinesterase (AChE) at the neuromuscular junction has one of the fastest turnover rates known. What is the approximate catalytic rate, and why are organophosphate inhibitors of AChE so dangerous?
options: AChE hydrolyzes ~25,000 ACh molecules per second per active site; organophosphate inhibitors (sarin, VX) form covalent bonds with the catalytic serine residue that are initially reversible but undergo 'aging' (dealkylation) within minutes to hours, becoming irreversible — this causes lethal accumulation of ACh at both nicotinic (muscle paralysis) and muscarinic (bradycardia, bronchospasm) synapses
AChE has a slow catalytic rate of ~10 molecules per second, and organophosphates are only mildly toxic
Organophosphates bind reversibly to AChE and are easily displaced by washing
AChE inhibition by organophosphates affects only the central nervous system, not peripheral muscles
questions.explanation: AChE is one of the fastest enzymes known, operating near the diffusion limit with a turnover number (kcat) of ~25,000 s-1. The enzyme contains a deep active site gorge (~20 Å) with a catalytic triad (Ser203, His447, Glu334) and a peripheral anionic site that initially binds ACh's quaternary ammonium group. Organophosphate (OP) nerve agents (sarin, soman, tabun, VX) and pesticides (malathion, parathion) phosphorylate the catalytic Ser203, forming a phosphoserine adduct that blocks ACh hydrolysis. Initially, this bond can be broken by nucleophilic reactivators (oximes like pralidoxime/2-PAM). However, within minutes to hours, the OP-enzyme complex undergoes 'aging' — loss of one alkyl group from the phosphorus atom — creating an extremely stable, negatively charged phosphonate adduct that cannot be reactivated. Aging half-times: soman ~2 min (extremely dangerous), sarin ~5 hr, VX ~48 hr. ACh accumulation causes: nicotinic effects (fasciculations → paralysis of respiratory muscles), muscarinic effects (SLUDGE: salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation, GI distress, emesis; plus bradycardia and bronchospasm), and CNS effects (seizures, coma). Treatment: atropine (muscarinic antagonist) + pralidoxime (before aging) + diazepam (anticonvulsant).

questions.question: Hydrostatic skeletons enable movement in soft-bodied animals. How does a hydrostatic skeleton work in an earthworm during locomotion?
options: Earthworm movement relies entirely on mucus secretion creating a slippery surface for passive sliding
The earthworm has an internal bony skeleton that supports its body
Earthworms move by ciliary action on their ventral surface, like planaria

Fluid-filled coelomic compartments act as incompressible hydraulic chambers — contraction of circular muscles in a segment increases internal pressure, elongating the segment (because fluid volume is constant, decreased diameter means increased length), while contraction of longitudinal muscles shortens and widens the segment; peristaltic waves of alternating circular and longitudinal contraction propagate posteriorly, with setae providing grip
questions.explanation: Hydrostatic skeletons function through the incompressibility of fluid (water) contained in a body cavity. In earthworms, the coelom is divided into segmental compartments by septa, allowing independent control of each segment. The body wall contains two muscle layers: outer circular muscles and inner longitudinal muscles. Because coelomic fluid is incompressible, the body segment has a constant volume. When circular muscles contract, the segment's diameter decreases and pressure increases, forcing the segment to elongate (V = πr²L, so decreased r increases L). When longitudinal muscles contract, the segment shortens and widens. During locomotion, peristaltic waves propagate from anterior to posterior: (1) Circular muscles contract in anterior segments, making them thin and long (extending forward). (2) Longitudinal muscles contract in posterior segments, making them short and wide (pulling the rear forward). (3) Setae (small bristles) on each segment extend during shortening to anchor that segment, and retract during elongation to allow sliding. The alternating contraction pattern moves at ~3-4 cm/s. Each segment functions somewhat independently due to septal compartmentalization. Similar hydrostatic systems are found in sea anemones, nematodes, and the tube feet of echinoderms.

questions.question: Exoskeletal locomotion in arthropods presents unique mechanical challenges. How do arthropod muscles attach to the exoskeleton and generate movement?
options: Arthropod muscles attach to the internal surface of the cuticle via tonofibrillae (tendon cells) at apodemes (infoldings of the exoskeleton) — muscles span across joints and work as antagonistic pairs because the rigid cuticle cannot be compressed; movement is limited to the joints between sclerites, creating lever systems with mechanical advantages determined by the geometry of muscle attachment relative to the joint pivot
Arthropod muscles attach directly to the external surface of the exoskeleton
Arthropods use hydraulic pressure exclusively for movement, similar to hydrostatic skeletons
Arthropod muscles are identical to vertebrate muscles and attach via tendons made of collagen
questions.explanation: Arthropod locomotion relies on the interaction between internal muscles and the external rigid exoskeleton (cuticle). Key features: (1) Muscle attachment — muscles connect to the internal cuticle surface through specialized epidermal cells called tonofibrillae (or tendon cells). In many cases, the cuticle forms internal projections called apodemes that increase the surface area for muscle attachment, functioning analogously to vertebrate tendons but made of chitin-protein matrix. (2) Lever mechanics — the rigid exoskeleton cannot be deformed (unlike hydrostatic skeletons), so all movement occurs at joints (flexible articular membranes between rigid sclerites). Muscles span across joints and work as antagonistic pairs (flexors and extensors). The ratio of the muscle attachment distance to the joint output distance determines the mechanical advantage. Most arthropod joints favor velocity ratio over force — muscles attach close to the joint pivot, producing fast but relatively weak movements. (3) Some arthropods use hydraulic assistance: spiders extend their legs using hemolymph pressure (they lack extensor muscles in some leg joints), and fleas store elastic energy in resilin pads for jumping. (4) Arthropod muscles are striated, use the same actin-myosin system, but can have much longer sarcomeres (~6-10 µm) than vertebrate muscle (~2.5 µm). Option B reverses attachment. Option C oversimplifies. Option D ignores chitin-based attachment.

questions.question:
Match the following locomotion types with their energy-saving mechanisms:
(I) Running (terrestrial)
(II) Flying (birds)
(III) Swimming (fish)
(IV) Brachiation (gibbons)

(P) Undulatory body waves generate thrust by pushing water backward; mucus reduces friction, lateral line detects hydrodynamic pressure for schooling in energy-saving formations
(Q) Elastic energy storage in tendons (especially Achilles tendon and digital flexors) functions as a spring, returning ~93% of stored elastic energy each stride and reducing metabolic cost by ~50%
(R) Pendulum-like swinging conserves kinetic energy by converting it to potential energy at the top of each swing, then back to kinetic energy on the downswing
(S) Lift-to-drag ratios optimized by wing shape (high aspect ratio); dynamic soaring and V-formation flight exploit air currents to reduce energy expenditure by up to 70%
options: I-Q, II-S, III-P, IV-R
I-S, II-P, III-R, IV-Q
I-R, II-Q, III-S, IV-P
I-P, II-R, III-Q, IV-S
questions.explanation: Each locomotion mode has evolved specific energy-saving mechanisms. Running (I-Q): Mammalian running exploits elastic energy storage in tendons and ligaments. The Achilles tendon and plantar ligaments stretch during the landing phase, storing elastic energy, then recoil during push-off, returning ~93% of the stored energy (only 7% is lost as heat). This makes tendons far more efficient than muscles at energy return. In kangaroos, elastic energy storage in the Achilles tendon is so efficient that hopping at moderate speeds costs less energy than walking. The nuchal ligament in running animals (dogs, horses) stores energy from head movements. Flying (II-S): Birds have evolved multiple energy-saving flight strategies. Wing aspect ratio (span/chord) determines the lift-to-drag ratio — albatrosses have aspect ratios of ~15, enabling dynamic soaring using wind gradients over ocean waves with almost no flapping. V-formation flight reduces induced drag by ~65% for trailing birds by exploiting the upwash from the leading bird's wingtip vortices. Swimming (III-P): Fish use undulatory locomotion, with body waves generating thrust following the principles of resistive and reactive force theory. Schooling in diamond formations reduces drag. Brachiation (IV-R): Gibbons swing through trees using pendulum mechanics, converting kinetic to potential energy and back with ~80% efficiency.

questions.question: The human lens focuses light by changing its shape through the process of accommodation. What is the mechanism of accommodation, and how does it change with age?
options: Contraction of the ciliary muscle reduces tension on the zonule fibers (suspensory ligaments), allowing the elastic lens to become more convex (increase its refractive power) for near vision — with age, the lens gradually loses elasticity due to cross-linking of crystallin proteins, leading to presbyopia (inability to focus on near objects), which typically becomes noticeable around age 40-45
The lens is made rigid by collagen and cannot change shape in any species
Accommodation works by changing the distance between the lens and retina, similar to a camera's focus mechanism
The iris adjusts the focal length by changing its diameter
questions.explanation: Accommodation is the process by which the eye adjusts its optical power to focus on objects at different distances. In the resting (unaccommodated) state, the ciliary muscle is relaxed, the zonule fibers (suspensory ligaments) are taut, and they pull the lens into a flatter shape — suited for distant vision. For near vision, the ciliary muscle contracts (parasympathetic innervation via CN III), reducing the circumference of the ciliary ring. This releases tension on the zonules, allowing the inherently elastic lens to assume a more spherical (convex) shape due to its elastic capsule. The increased curvature increases refractive power by ~12-14 diopters in young adults, allowing focus on objects as close as ~10 cm. With age, lens crystallin proteins undergo progressive glycation, cross-linking, disulfide bond formation, and compaction, causing the lens to lose elasticity. This condition — presbyopia — typically becomes clinically significant around age 40-45 when the near point of accommodation recedes beyond comfortable reading distance (~25 cm). By age 60, accommodative amplitude is reduced to ~1 diopter. This is universal and independent of refractive error (affects both myopic and hyperopic individuals). Treatment includes reading glasses, bifocals, or progressive lenses. Option B is incorrect. Option C describes a mechanism used by fish (lens movement) but not mammals. Option D confuses iris function.

questions.question: Myosin light chain phosphorylation regulates smooth muscle contraction. What kinase is responsible, and how is relaxation achieved?
options: Protein kinase C is the primary kinase, and relaxation occurs through troponin-mediated inhibition

Ca2+-calmodulin-activated myosin light chain kinase (MLCK) phosphorylates the 20 kDa regulatory light chain at Ser19, activating myosin ATPase — relaxation requires dephosphorylation by myosin light chain phosphatase (MLCP), which can be inhibited by the RhoA/Rho-kinase pathway (Ca2+ sensitization), maintaining contraction at lower Ca2+ levels
cAMP-dependent protein kinase activates contraction, and relaxation requires ATP depletion
Tyrosine kinases phosphorylate myosin, and phosphatases are not involved in relaxation
questions.explanation: Smooth muscle contraction regulation centers on thick filament (myosin-based) control, unlike striated muscle's thin filament (troponin-tropomyosin) regulation. Activation: When intracellular Ca2+ rises (from SR release via IP3 receptors and/or extracellular entry through voltage-gated and receptor-operated Ca2+ channels), Ca2+ binds calmodulin (4 Ca2+/CaM). Ca2+-CaM activates MLCK, which phosphorylates Ser19 on the 20 kDa regulatory light chain (RLC) of myosin II. Phosphorylation relieves an autoinhibitory conformation, allowing myosin ATPase activity and cross-bridge cycling with actin. Relaxation: MLCP (PP1M) dephosphorylates RLC, returning myosin to its autoinhibited state. MLCP is a trimeric holoenzyme containing PP1c catalytic subunit, MYPT1 targeting subunit, and M20 subunit. Ca2+ sensitization: The RhoA/Rho-kinase (ROCK) pathway can phosphorylate MYPT1, inhibiting MLCP. This maintains contraction at relatively low Ca2+ levels — important for sustained vascular tone. ROCK inhibitors (fasudil, Y-27632) cause vasodilation and are therapeutic targets for hypertension and vasospasm. Additionally, CPI-17 (an endogenous PP1 inhibitor) is activated by protein kinase C and also inhibits MLCP. Option A is partially correct but not the primary pathway. Option C misidentifies the kinase. Option D is incorrect.

questions.question: A psychophysics experiment measures hearing thresholds across frequency. Results show the human ear is most sensitive at 2-5 kHz (threshold ~0 dB SPL), with sensitivity decreasing at both lower and higher frequencies (threshold ~60 dB SPL at 50 Hz and at 15 kHz). What explains this frequency-dependent sensitivity pattern?
options: Hair cells at the base and apex of the cochlea are inherently less sensitive than those in the middle
All frequencies are equally transduced by the cochlea, and the difference is created by psychological bias
The brain actively suppresses low and high frequencies through descending auditory pathways

The sensitivity curve (equal loudness contour/audiogram) reflects the combined resonance properties of the outer and middle ear — the ear canal resonance (~2-4 kHz, ~10-15 dB gain) and middle ear ossicular impedance matching (peak transmission at 1-3 kHz) together create a bandpass filter centered at 2-5 kHz, the frequency range most important for human speech perception
questions.explanation: The human hearing sensitivity curve (audiogram) reflects the acoustic transfer function of the outer and middle ear rather than cochlear sensitivity, which is relatively uniform across frequency. Two main resonant systems create the characteristic U-shaped sensitivity curve: (1) Outer ear canal resonance: The external auditory canal (~2.5 cm length, closed at one end by the tympanic membrane) acts as a quarter-wave resonator with a fundamental resonance at ~2.7 kHz (λ/4 = 2.5 cm, f = v/4L = 340/0.1 = ~3400 Hz). The pinna adds additional frequency-dependent gain. Together, the outer ear provides ~10-15 dB amplification at 2-4 kHz. (2) Middle ear transfer function: The ossicular chain (malleus-incus-stapes) performs impedance matching between the low-impedance air-filled ear canal and the high-impedance fluid-filled cochlea. Two mechanisms: area ratio (tympanic membrane ~55 mm2 vs. stapes footplate ~3.2 mm2 = ~17:1 area ratio = ~25 dB gain) and lever ratio (malleus-incus lever = ~1.3:1 = ~2 dB). Total theoretical gain: ~27 dB. This impedance matching is most efficient at 1-3 kHz. The combined effect peaks at 2-5 kHz, coinciding with the frequency range of human speech formants (F1-F4). Option B ignores physical acoustics. Option C is secondary. Option A is largely incorrect.

questions.question: Endoskeletons and exoskeletons each have advantages and disadvantages. What is the primary biomechanical limitation of an exoskeleton that constrains arthropod body size?
options: An exoskeleton must be periodically shed (molted) for growth, leaving the animal vulnerable; more critically, as body size increases, exoskeleton mass scales with the cube of body length while structural strength scales with the cross-sectional area (square), making large exoskeletons too heavy relative to their strength — this is why the largest terrestrial arthropods (coconut crabs ~4 kg) are dwarfed by vertebrates with endoskeletons
Exoskeletons prevent all movement, so arthropods above a certain size cannot walk
Exoskeletons cannot form joints, limiting the range of motion as size increases
The only limitation is that exoskeletons are transparent, providing no protection from UV radiation at larger sizes
questions.explanation: Exoskeletal body plans face fundamental scaling constraints. As body size increases isometrically (all dimensions scale equally): (1) Body mass scales with volume (L³), while the structural strength of the exoskeleton scales with its cross-sectional area (L²). This means that a 10× increase in linear dimension increases mass 1000× but strength only 100×. The exoskeleton's weight eventually exceeds its ability to support the animal, especially on land where buoyancy doesn't help. (2) Molting vulnerability — arthropods must shed their exoskeleton to grow, a process (ecdysis) during which the new cuticle is soft and the animal is extremely vulnerable to predation, desiccation, and mechanical damage. For large animals, the time required for the new cuticle to harden increases, extending the vulnerable period. The molting fluid must also be resorbed efficiently, which becomes harder at larger sizes. (3) Respiratory constraints — arthropods use tracheae (insects) or book lungs (arachnids) for gas exchange. Tracheal diffusion becomes insufficient at large body sizes (O₂ diffusion limits ~5-10 cm in modern atmosphere). In contrast, endoskeletons (bone) grow continuously without molting, can be internally remodeled, and mass scales more favorably because bones can be hollow (reducing mass while maintaining bending strength). The largest marine arthropods (Japanese spider crab, ~19 kg) benefit from buoyancy.

questions.question: Sensory receptor adaptation allows organisms to detect changes against a constant background. How does the mechanism of adaptation differ between slowly adapting and rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors?
options: Slowly adapting receptors are simply damaged rapidly adapting receptors that can no longer properly filter stimuli
All mechanoreceptors adapt at the same rate, and the difference is entirely in central processing
Rapidly adapting receptors have weaker ion channels that inactivate faster

Rapidly adapting receptors (Pacinian corpuscles, Meissner's corpuscles) have structural features that filter sustained stimuli — the Pacinian corpuscle's lamellae redistribute mechanical energy so only transient forces reach the nerve ending; slowly adapting receptors (Merkel cells, Ruffini endings) lack such filtering structures and continue to generate receptor potentials proportional to steady-state stimulus magnitude
questions.explanation: Sensory adaptation in mechanoreceptors involves both mechanical filtering and intrinsic neural properties. Rapidly adapting (RA) receptors respond to stimulus onset and offset but not to sustained stimulation. The Pacinian corpuscle is the best-studied example: its ~60 concentric lamellae (separated by viscous fluid) act as a mechanical high-pass filter. When sustained pressure is applied, the viscoelastic lamellae redistribute stress within ~50 ms so that no force is transmitted to the central nerve ending — only the initial transient passes through. Loewenstein's classic experiment proved this: removing the lamellae converted the corpuscle from rapidly to slowly adapting. Meissner's corpuscles achieve rapid adaptation through their loosely layered structure that slips under sustained pressure. Slowly adapting (SA) receptors lack elaborate filtering structures. Merkel cell-neurite complexes (SA-I) produce sustained receptor potentials throughout stimulus duration because the rigid cell-neurite coupling faithfully transmits static forces. Ruffini endings (SA-II) maintain tension through their fusiform collagenous capsule. In addition to mechanical filtering, intrinsic neural adaptation occurs through ion channel mechanisms: Na+ channel slow inactivation, Ca2+-activated K+ channels, and M-current (KCNQ) all reduce excitability during prolonged stimulation. SA receptors have lower expression of adaptation channels. Option B ignores peripheral mechanisms. Option C oversimplifies. Option A is nonsensical.

questions.question: The organization of skeletal muscle follows a hierarchical structure. What is the correct hierarchy from largest to smallest?
options: Whole muscle → fascicle (bundle of fibers) → muscle fiber (single cell, multinucleated syncytium) → myofibril (contractile strand) → sarcomere (basic contractile unit between Z-discs) → myofilaments (thick filaments of myosin and thin filaments of actin/tropomyosin/troponin)
Whole muscle → sarcomere → myofibril → muscle fiber → fascicle → myofilament
Whole muscle → muscle fiber → fascicle → myofilament → sarcomere → myofibril
Fascicle → whole muscle → myofibril → muscle fiber → myofilament → sarcomere
questions.explanation: Skeletal muscle has a highly organized hierarchical structure, with each level wrapped in connective tissue: (1) Whole muscle — surrounded by epimysium (dense connective tissue). (2) Fascicles — bundles of 10-100 muscle fibers, wrapped by perimysium. Fascicle organization determines muscle architecture (parallel, pennate, convergent). (3) Muscle fiber — a single cell (~10-100 µm diameter, up to 30 cm length in sartorius) that is a multinucleated syncytium formed by fusion of myoblasts during development. Each fiber is wrapped by endomysium and enclosed by the sarcolemma (plasma membrane). Hundreds to thousands of nuclei are located peripherally beneath the sarcolemma. (4) Myofibrils — ~1-2 µm diameter cylindrical organelles that run the entire length of the fiber, containing the contractile apparatus. A single fiber may contain hundreds to thousands of myofibrils. (5) Sarcomere — the basic contractile unit, ~2.0-2.5 µm in resting human muscle, defined as the region between two Z-discs. (6) Myofilaments — thick filaments (myosin II, ~1.6 µm, ~300 myosin molecules per filament) and thin filaments (F-actin + tropomyosin + troponin, ~1.0 µm, ~360 actin monomers per filament). The T-tubule system and sarcoplasmic reticulum run between myofibrils, enabling rapid, uniform activation.

questions.question: The gate control theory of pain, proposed by Melzack and Wall, explains how non-painful input can modulate pain perception. What is the basic mechanism?
options: Pain perception is determined solely by the intensity of the peripheral stimulus with no central modulation
Pain signals are exclusively processed in the thalamus with no spinal cord modulation
All sensory fibers equally contribute to pain perception regardless of diameter

Activation of large-diameter myelinated Aβ fibers (carrying touch/pressure information) stimulates inhibitory interneurons in the substantia gelatinosa (lamina II) of the spinal cord dorsal horn, which inhibit transmission of pain signals from small-diameter C-fiber and Aδ nociceptors to projection neurons — this is why rubbing an injured area reduces pain perception
questions.explanation: The gate control theory (Melzack and Wall, 1965) was revolutionary in proposing that pain perception is not a simple direct transmission from nociceptors to the brain, but is modulated at the spinal cord level by a 'gate' mechanism. The gate is located in the substantia gelatinosa (SG, lamina II) of the dorsal horn. The model: (1) Small-diameter fibers (Aδ and C nociceptors) carry pain signals and excite transmission (T) cells (projection neurons in lamina V) while inhibiting SG inhibitory interneurons — effectively opening the gate. (2) Large-diameter Aβ fibers (mechanoreceptors for touch, pressure) excite both T cells and SG inhibitory interneurons. The SG interneurons inhibit T cell transmission — effectively closing the gate. (3) When both are active simultaneously, Aβ-driven inhibition can outweigh nociceptive input, reducing pain transmission to the brain. This explains why: rubbing a painful area reduces pain (Aβ activation closes the gate), TENS (transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation) provides pain relief, and why acute injury initially hurts less than expected (initial Aβ activation from impact). The theory has been refined to include descending modulation from the periaqueductal gray (PAG), endogenous opioids (enkephalins, endorphins), and wide dynamic range neurons, but the core concept remains valid and clinically relevant.

questions.question: A researcher wants to test whether a specific population of motor cortex neurons encodes movement direction. Which experimental design would provide the strongest evidence?
options: Lesion the motor cortex and observe whether the animal can still move

Record from individual motor cortex neurons while a monkey performs a center-out reaching task to targets in multiple directions — construct tuning curves showing each neuron's firing rate as a function of movement direction, demonstrating that neurons have a 'preferred direction' with cosine-tuned firing rate profiles; then use population vector analysis to show that the summed weighted activity of ~100+ neurons accurately predicts the actual movement direction
Measure blood flow to the motor cortex using PET scanning during different movements
Stimulate the motor cortex electrically and observe which muscles twitch
questions.explanation: Georgopoulos et al. (1982, 1986) pioneered the center-out reaching task to study directional tuning in motor cortex. The experimental design: (1) A monkey is trained to move a manipulandum from a central start position to one of 8 targets arranged in a circle (0°, 45°, 90°... 315°). (2) Extracellular microelectrodes record single-neuron activity during each reach. (3) Each neuron's firing rate is plotted as a function of target direction, revealing a tuning curve. Most M1 neurons show broad, approximately cosine-shaped directional tuning — maximum firing for movements in one 'preferred direction' (PD) and minimum for the opposite direction. (4) The population vector is calculated by summing vectors pointing in each neuron's PD, weighted by its firing rate. With ~150 neurons, the population vector predicts actual movement direction with ~95% accuracy, even predicting reaction time and movement trajectory. This demonstrates that direction is encoded by the collective activity of broadly tuned neurons (population coding), not by individual specialist neurons. Option A tests necessity but not encoding. Option C lacks single-neuron resolution. Option D maps motor outputs but not natural movement encoding.

questions.question: Otoacoustic emissions (OAEs) are sounds produced by the cochlea itself. What generates these emissions and what is their clinical significance?
options: OAEs originate from neural activity in the auditory nerve
OAEs are produced by middle ear muscles contracting rhythmically
OAEs are caused by blood flow through cochlear vessels and have no diagnostic value

OAEs are generated by the electromotile activity of outer hair cells — prestin-driven length changes amplify basilar membrane vibrations, and some of this mechanical energy propagates backward through the cochlea and middle ear, emerging as faint sounds (typically -10 to +20 dB SPL) detectable by a sensitive microphone in the ear canal; their presence indicates functional OHCs and is used clinically to screen neonatal hearing
